headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rob, and thank you all for joining us on the call this morning to review JCPenney's first quarter earnings. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the
componenttext:
Thank you, Rob, and thank you all for joining us on the call this morning to review JCPenney's first quarter earnings. 
Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, which reflect the company's current view of future events and financial performance. The words expect, plan, anticipate, belief and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements. 
Any such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, and the company's future results of operations could differ materially from historical results or current expectations. For more details on these risks, please refer to the company's Form 10-K and other SEC filings. 
Also, please note that no portion of this call may be rebroadcast in any form without the prior written consent of JCPenney. Replays of today's webcast will be available for 90 days. For those listening after May 14, 2010, please note that this recording will not be updated, and it is possible that the information discussed will no longer be current. 
On this morning's call, we will have two speakers: Mike Ullman, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Bob Cavanaugh, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Now, I'll turn it over to Mike Ullman.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us today to review our results for the first quarter, which we believe put us on a solid footing for the year. Bob will cover the first quarter financial highlights in just a moment, but I'd like to give you some ke
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us today to review our results for the first quarter, which we believe put us on a solid footing for the year. Bob will cover the first quarter financial highlights in just a moment, but I'd like to give you some key highlights for the quarter. 
On the sales front, the first quarter, which we expected to be the toughest of the year, came in ahead of what we originally anticipated, up 1.3%. Across our sector, March was the strongest month and April the weakest due to the Easter shift and to consumers retreating somewhat in the latter half of the month, due to weather and the lack of any appointment shopping event during that time. 
We were pleased that our traffic trends were positive for the quarter. Mall traffic was up approximately 1% and off-mall traffic was up a couple hundred basis points, higher than our mall traffic, consistent with our trends. I am proud of the way our team's managed the business, which allowed us to deliver higher EPS than we had expected. This was due to better gross margins, up 90 basis points, which reflects the ongoing commitment across our organization to keep expenses at appropriate levels, the success of our Red Zone Clearance strategy, better sell-throughs on new merchandise reflecting positive response to our spring assortments and other new styles we introduced, and improved pricing strategies in certain areas as well. 
Those of you who were at our analyst meeting last month got to hear first-hand from our top merchants about the strategies they're putting in place in their respective areas of the business. I'm pleased to report that all divisions except Home had sales gains for the quarter, reflecting that these initiatives are already starting to pay off. For example, Men's performed very well during the quarter, leading our divisions. Steve Lawrence's team spent last year editing assortments and clarifying our price offerings and it's worked well. We're seeing marked improvements in Men's Sportswear where the addition of Joe Joseph Abboud, Irreverent, and our restyled J. ferrar are generating excitement. 
Young Men's and Athletic Sportswear were also strong performers, and we continue to expand our market share in these areas. Another highlight of the quarter was the ongoing role of SEPHORA Inside JCPenney. This highly successful concept is now in 193 of our stores. We plan to open additional 37 locations this year, for a total of 230 by year end.
We're starting to see positive momentum in our center core businesses, such as Shoes and Handbags. After re-evaluating our approach, we introduced a deeper assortment of modern updated styles and have featured them as part of head-to-toe looks in our Little Red Book for spring. As a result, handbags and shoes were very strong sellers for the Mother's Day selling period. 
The Little Red Book in Women's and Matters of Style book in Men's also generated traffic on jcp.com. The alignment of our assortments across stores and dot-com is working. Both apparel divisions saw double-digit increases in their online businesses for the quarter. 
Overall, jcp.com was up approximately 1% over last year. This reflects the impact of a softer Home business and the restructuring of some aspects of our catalog business. As you know, Home is a significant part of our business on- and off-line. John Tighe, the new [indiscernible] in charge of Home, has been on the job for two months and is putting together a solid plan to drive growth in both hard and soft Home businesses in stores and online. 
We ended the first quarter with inventory down 7.2% versus a year ago. Like most retailers, we cut back our inventory last year in order to tightly manage our business, recover gross margin deterioration and maintain our profitability and financial strength. We finished the first quarter with inventory down less than 1%, and we'll continue to rebuild our inventory levels to capitalize on the general return for the consumer environment. You'll continue to see our inventory levels improve on a relative basis as we move to the second quarter and prepare for stronger sales growth in the back half of the year. 
Taken together, these merchandising initiatives, along with our strategic initiatives around JCP Rewards, which now has over 5 million members, the Red Zone Clearance strategy, and jcp.com will continue to drive our top line sales performance. 
Looking ahead to the second quarter, the second quarter includes a few appointment shopping events and JCPenney and our team of 150,000 associates are well prepared for them. For Mother's Day, we launched our fine jewelry collection of One Kiss by Cindy Crawford. It's off to a strong start after only a few weeks. 
For Father's Day, we expect that our stylish value-priced apparel and gift offerings will resonate well with shoppers, like our assortment of St. John's Bay's polos or our stylish assortments of ties and accessories. 
Also, the month of June will not be as big of a clearance month as in last year. This year, we will offer more wear-now goods like shorts and tees. When combined with our successful Red Zone Clearance strategy, we believe this change in our merchandise offering could benefit June sales volume. 
And July begins our focus on back-to-school. We'll be showing kids, teens and their moms that JCPenney is the one-stop shop with the style and price points that are sharper than the specialty stores in the mall that cater to younger shoppers. They'll discover that JCPenney continues to be the denim destination for kids and teens for back-to-school with brands like Levi, City Streets, Decree and Arizona. 
In addition, our new private brand uproar for tweens offers cool, edgy and functional styles including premium denim at sharp prices. We're capitalizing our success in the surf-and-skate brands such as RS By Sheckler, rusty, and Zoo York by expanding those brands in the younger Boys and Girls segments. Our younger shoppers are pleased with this expansion as initial sell-throughs are good. 
Supergirl by Nastia will launch excessively at JCPenney for back-to-school. Supergirl, which celebrates Olympian Nastia Liukin, is an activewear collection adding to one of our best categories in Children's. These new brands will all be featured in our back-to-school marketing, which incorporates our "New look. New day. Who knew." messaging and includes a wide range of interactive, mobile and social media components that kids and teens will find compelling. 
We have a lot of exciting initiatives coming in the second quarter, and taking all these factors into account, we expect that comparable store sales will rise approximately 2Â½% to 3% in the second quarter. Correspondingly, we expect the earnings per share to be in the range of $0.10 to $0.13 per share. Bob Cavanaugh will discuss more about this in a moment. 
Looking beyond the second quarter, we have major style initiatives coming online for the back half of the year that will further establish JCPenney as the style destination, driving sales and market share growth. These include the launch of Liz Claiborne, a lifestyle brand in approximately 30 categories. Liz is one of the most desired and enduring brands with our existing customer segment and will drive new customers to JCPenney as they seek out where to find the Liz brand that beginning in August will only be found at JCPenney. 
Shortly after that, we'll introduce MNG by Mango as the centerpiece for our increasingly exceptional Contemporary offering. Mango is one of the top five fast fashion retail brands in the world and JCPenney will be the only U.S. store to offer it in a compelling way that will attract a younger customer to JCPenney. 
Also for fall, we're excited about our new partnership with People StyleWatch, where their top editors will select seasons must-haves from our JCPenney assortments. We believe this new partnership will give a highly credible third-party endorsement to our merchandise and our style authority. 
As we execute on all we have coming, we're keeping in mind that the economy and the consumer environment remain unpredictable. In light of that, we'll continue to execute our business with discipline, monitoring our costs and looking at our expenses very closely. 
We continue to expect that comparable store sales should increase in the low single digits for the full year and due to our continued success in protecting our gross margin, we also now expect that EPS should be approximately $1.64 per share for the year compared to our previous guidance of $1.55 per share.
With that, I'll now turn the call over to Bob Cavanaugh to go more deeply into our results for the first quarter and our future outlook.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. Our first quarter results demonstrate continued performance improvement for both top line sales and bottom line profitability. This morning, we reported earnings of $0.25 per share for the first quarter, which exc
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. Our first quarter results demonstrate continued performance improvement for both top line sales and bottom line profitability. This morning, we reported earnings of $0.25 per share for the first quarter, which exceeded our original expectations of $0.16 to $0.20 per share. Our gross margin of 41.4% reflects better-than-expected sales performance achieved during the quarter and good early season sell-through of spring seasonal merchandise. 
SG&A expenses increased 2.7% in dollars, which was slightly higher than our original guidance, but well managed as we invested to support the increased sales volume. Including the impact of lower qualified pension expense, total expenses were leveraged and decreased 30 basis points to 37.5% of sales. 
Operating income for the quarter was $155 million, compared with $106 million in last year's period, an increase of 46.2%. Non-GAAP adjusted operating income, which excludes non-cash qualified pension expense, increased 12.3%. As a percent of sales, operating income increased 120 basis points and was 3.9% in the first quarter, compared with 2.7% last year. Excluding the qualified pension expense, adjusted operating income increased 50 basis points to 5.3%. Interest expense for the quarter was $59 million, and the income tax rate was 37Â½%. 
Moving on to our financial condition. The company remains in a very solid position, with strong financial flexibility to support our growth plans. As of the end of the first quarter, the company had cash and cash equivalents of approximately $2.4 billion. In March, we retired $393 million of long-term debt using existing cash balance, and we ended the quarter with long-term debt of approximately $3 billion. 
You may have also seen that on April 26, we commenced the debt tender offer to purchase $300 million of long-term debt securities. The tender offer period will expire on May 21, and any impact to interest expense or expected earnings per share will be disclosed after the results of the tender are complete. 
Capital expenditures for the first quarter were $116 million, in line with expectations and compared with $156 million last year.
During the first quarter, we opened two new stores. Separately, we also closed one store located in an underperforming mall, which brought our store count as of the end of the quarter to 1,109 stores. We also added 38 SEPHORA Inside JCPenney locations, bringing our total for the concept to 193 locations, and we continue to anticipate full year capital expenditures to be approximately $500 million. 
Turning now to our outlook for the second quarter and full year. For the second quarter, comparable store sales are expected to increase in the range of 2Â½% to 3%. With respect to monthly sales, the shift of Memorial Day will have a negative impact on May sales and a similar benefit to June. We expect May comparable store sales to be below the quarter, June above the quarter, and July in line with the quarter. Total sales are expected to increase approximately 54 basis points less than the comparable store sales increase. 
Gross margins are expected to improve modestly over last year's second quarter, and we expect an increase of approximately 4Â½% in SG&A dollars primarily from new stores opened since last year's first quarter, minimum wage increases and a resumption of merit increases for our associates. 
In addition, our guidance for the second quarter includes depreciation and amortization of approximately $123 million, pre-opening expenses of approximately $1 million, net interest expense of $56 million and an effective tax rate of approximately 38%. For the second quarter, we expect earnings to be in the range of $0.10 to $0.13 per share, and for the full year, we now expect 2010 earnings per share to be approximately $1.64. This update includes our first quarter results ahead of plan and a modest improvement in our outlook for the remaining three quarters.
In summary, our liquidity and financial conditions continue to be very strong and well positioned to support the initiatives of our long-range plan as we focus on expanding market share and delivering sustainable, long-term earnings growth. With that, I'll turn the call back over to Mike Ullman.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob. As I said earlier, we believe the first quarters to be toughest of our year. We're very pleased what we have coming into the second quarter and certainly in the back half of the year. I'd like to again thank our more than 150,000 associate
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob. As I said earlier, we believe the first quarters to be toughest of our year. We're very pleased what we have coming into the second quarter and certainly in the back half of the year. I'd like to again thank our more than 150,000 associates for the continued hard work and dedication to delivering a unique and exciting shopping experience to our customers every day. 
We have a long-range plan in place to continue the transformation of JCPenney that we began five years ago and position our company as the growth leader in our industry on both the top and the bottom line. We look forward to updating you on how we are doing on our progress to achieve $5 billion of incremental sales, a $5 earnings per share in the next five years, 555 as we discussed at the analyst meeting. With that, we will now open the call to your questions.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from the line of Deborah Weinswig with Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from the line of Deborah Weinswig with Citigroup.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: So specifically looking at gross margins in the first quarter and then looking at the second, obviously very strong performance. Can you talk about -- I think your guidance was originally for it to increase slightly in the first quarter and obviously, we
componenttext: So specifically looking at gross margins in the first quarter and then looking at the second, obviously very strong performance. Can you talk about -- I think your guidance was originally for it to increase slightly in the first quarter and obviously, we saw much better performance than that. Can you talk about, specifically, the drivers of the differences in the first quarter? And then also for the guidance in the second quarter to be for modest improvement?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the first quarter, we really had three factors that contributed: One was better markup on, particularly, in private label coming out of resourcing operation; a better shortage result, which is a factor of improved disciplines in the stores; as well as
componenttext: In the first quarter, we really had three factors that contributed: One was better markup on, particularly, in private label coming out of resourcing operation; a better shortage result, which is a factor of improved disciplines in the stores; as well as our new clearance strategy, which performed at higher AUR than our previous strategy. And I would say going forward those factors will hopefully continue. The shortage may not be repeated because that's based on the number of stores that we inventory by quarter.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then can you also talk about the JCPenney Rewards program? What are you seeing in terms of the impact? Any change in terms of frequency of visitor or ticket size as well?
componenttext: And then can you also talk about the JCPenney Rewards program? What are you seeing in terms of the impact? Any change in terms of frequency of visitor or ticket size as well?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: We obviously see it as accretive. We know that Rewards customers shop more often and spend more while they're in the store. As we discussed at the analyst meeting, we are going to continue to grow the Rewards program and extend it to our credit customers
componenttext: We obviously see it as accretive. We know that Rewards customers shop more often and spend more while they're in the store. As we discussed at the analyst meeting, we are going to continue to grow the Rewards program and extend it to our credit customers in our credit file. So it's an important portion of our incremental sales growth plan for the rest of the year.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I think, just going back to our model, this is the first quarter since the second quarter of '07 where the company delivered a positive comp. In your opinion, Mike, what were the key drivers behind this performance?
componenttext: And then I think, just going back to our model, this is the first quarter since the second quarter of '07 where the company delivered a positive comp. In your opinion, Mike, what were the key drivers behind this performance?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think getting our inventory back into shape, obviously going through the downturn in the Bridge Plan, we were intentionally cautious about the kind of risk we were taking. I think that is starting to improve as our inventory position improves, and obvio
componenttext: I think getting our inventory back into shape, obviously going through the downturn in the Bridge Plan, we were intentionally cautious about the kind of risk we were taking. I think that is starting to improve as our inventory position improves, and obviously, went into the quarter down 7%, came out down 1.3% or something like that. I think that was a factor. Obviously, we have a number of things going on at the same time, one being the clearance strategy. We're pleased with the early results of that. That was a long process of engineering it for execution in our stores and the way that the merchandising flow is being handled. We see the June selling period benefiting from this as well because there'll be more wear-now merchandise on the floor and less of the clearance cadence in chunks as we had in the past. So I think, generally feel the initiatives we have are more loaded to the back half of the year in terms of Mango, Liz Claiborne, those kinds of things. Obviously, the dot-com business for us is double-digit ahead in the apparel categories, we're dragged down a bit by our Home performance and also some shifts we have in the way we're re-engineering the catalog business, which have an effect on dot-com as well.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Adrianne Shapira with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Adrianne Shapira with Goldman Sachs.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, just following on the June opportunity, in terms of the wear-now, the clearance, it seems like a big change and a big opportunity. Tell us how you plan on marketing that to capitalize on the sales and margin opportunity.
componenttext: Mike, just following on the June opportunity, in terms of the wear-now, the clearance, it seems like a big change and a big opportunity. Tell us how you plan on marketing that to capitalize on the sales and margin opportunity.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we never lack for marketing in the month of June. It was a question of the cadence, how we merchandise clearance. We used to merchandise clearance in specific periods of time where the Red Zone strategy is to have clearance on the floor essentially
componenttext: Well, we never lack for marketing in the month of June. It was a question of the cadence, how we merchandise clearance. We used to merchandise clearance in specific periods of time where the Red Zone strategy is to have clearance on the floor essentially all through the year with much, much easier to understand pricing. And as a result, it evens out the flow of clearance exiting our store, hopefully at better price points than previous strategy and that's what we've found so far. What's happened in the transition periods of June and January, our old strategy tended to not re-merchandise to the customer what the customers were actually buying to wear now during those periods. So while we're not experts on that at this point because we haven't experienced that in the month of June, we do anticipate that being more in business in tanks and tees, and we've watched what our competition has done during that period, we believe we have an opportunity to pick up share during that time frame.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of some specific quantifications we've been hearing about the Memorial Day shift, if you could put any sort of specifics in terms of the impact on to May and what it would do in terms of June?
componenttext: And then in terms of some specific quantifications we've been hearing about the Memorial Day shift, if you could put any sort of specifics in terms of the impact on to May and what it would do in terms of June?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: We think it's about a 150 to 200 basis point impact on that shift.
componenttext: We think it's about a 150 to 200 basis point impact on that shift.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then my question relates to SG&A. It sounds like we should expect some acceleration in the second quarter to 4Â½%. Maybe a little bit more specifics in terms of what's driving that acceleration? And then, if you could revisit how we should think about the
componenttext: Then my question relates to SG&A. It sounds like we should expect some acceleration in the second quarter to 4Â½%. Maybe a little bit more specifics in terms of what's driving that acceleration? And then, if you could revisit how we should think about the year? Your full-year guidance had been calling for a low, single digit increase in SG&A growth. Should we continue to expect that? And would that assume a deceleration in the back half as you lack easy year-ago comparisons?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the second half of your question, the answer is yes. On the first part of your question, there are some compensation issues in terms of minimum wage and some other adjustments we've made for our hourly associates that will have a bit of an impact in th
componenttext: On the second half of your question, the answer is yes. On the first part of your question, there are some compensation issues in terms of minimum wage and some other adjustments we've made for our hourly associates that will have a bit of an impact in the second quarter. But we believe that we're on track to deliver the SG&A we intend at the beginning of the year.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Growth margins, it looks like Q1, we're at peak levels and Q2, looks like we're on track to hit those as well. Just help us think about what's the right balance and how you think about what's the appropriate level of giving that compelling value offering,
componenttext: Growth margins, it looks like Q1, we're at peak levels and Q2, looks like we're on track to hit those as well. Just help us think about what's the right balance and how you think about what's the appropriate level of giving that compelling value offering, and also driving margin expansion?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of moving parts here. But generally, I would say our core competency in private product development, private brand development, is the key GP driver. Having said that, there's a few moving parts. Getting out of the Big Book catalog business
componenttext: There's a lot of moving parts here. But generally, I would say our core competency in private product development, private brand development, is the key GP driver. Having said that, there's a few moving parts. Getting out of the Big Book catalog business has had some impact on our margins being sharp on classification merchandise. We've been able to achieve in the men's business with the strong power of merchandising statements as very sharp price points has driven the men's business and is our best business at the moment. So these things all are kind of going back and forth. I think at the end of the day, our conception is you want to keep margins about the same so we can be aggressive in our pricing and give good value to the consumer. But they are at very high levels so the same is not necessarily a bad thing.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Michelle Clark of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Michelle Clark of Morgan Stanley.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the Home business in your prepared remarks, commenting that it was the one business for you guys that didn't see sales gains. We'd love to hear your thoughts on what's going on there. And then also related to Home, what is your expectation for the seco
componenttext: On the Home business in your prepared remarks, commenting that it was the one business for you guys that didn't see sales gains. We'd love to hear your thoughts on what's going on there. And then also related to Home, what is your expectation for the second quarter? And what type of sales performance for Home is embedded in your comp outlook?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's a fair question. I think we feel like there are a number of positions in Home, which have been quite successful the last several years being the introduction of Linden Street, our ability to attract a brand like Cindy Crawford Style, which
componenttext: I think that's a fair question. I think we feel like there are a number of positions in Home, which have been quite successful the last several years being the introduction of Linden Street, our ability to attract a brand like Cindy Crawford Style, which has resonated very online as well as in our stores. There've been a number of programs that we are proud of. Having said that, I'm not sure that we messaged the price points and the depth of our offer very effectively in the past. I think John Tighe is a very skilled merchant, and I think he and his team are putting together a solid plan, which I think will see a results in the second half of the year in terms of going after the business. Obviously, the two parts of the Home business, the Soft Home businesses, obviously very fashion-driven and more like the Apparel business and is doing well, but the Hard Home business, which is window covering and furniture, those businesses are harder to feel terrific about in the sense that the Home markets, as you know, if anything, are stagnant at best and possibly even down trending in some markets. So we actually look at Home as a positive because, frankly, we've languished a bit over the last couple of years, and we think there's upside. I think John and his team deserve a couple months to put it in place. And so far, I'm very pleased with the progress.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then for the second quarter, Mike, are you looking for a any pickup in Home or do you really expect that to come in the back half?
componenttext: And then for the second quarter, Mike, are you looking for a any pickup in Home or do you really expect that to come in the back half?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: We are seeing pick-up now in some of the Soft Home categories. So I would expect that to continue. The real question is the balance between online and in-store and the balance between Hard Home and Soft Home. I don't think it's going to be a major contrib
componenttext: We are seeing pick-up now in some of the Soft Home categories. So I would expect that to continue. The real question is the balance between online and in-store and the balance between Hard Home and Soft Home. I don't think it's going to be a major contributor for back-to-school because obviously, that's not the major Home preoccupation of the customer. But I would expect certainly by the fourth quarter we'll start to see a meaningful contribution of Home.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Chuck Grom of JP Morgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Chuck Grom of JP Morgan.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you just elaborate a little bit more on your comments about consumer retreating in the back half of April? And I guess there's some of your competitors over the past few days have - some have suggested that May sales are off to a little bit of a lackl
componenttext: Can you just elaborate a little bit more on your comments about consumer retreating in the back half of April? And I guess there's some of your competitors over the past few days have - some have suggested that May sales are off to a little bit of a lackluster start, but to your point earlier about event shopping, that we obviously had Mother's Day last week, and so can you just connect the dots for us on that front?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think our experience in April is probably any different than our competitors. I think that we never like to talk about the weather, but when you are in seasonal goods, and the Easter shift, the combination of the two is not favorable in the second
componenttext: I don't think our experience in April is probably any different than our competitors. I think that we never like to talk about the weather, but when you are in seasonal goods, and the Easter shift, the combination of the two is not favorable in the second half of the month. But we wouldn't comment on current business except to say that we believe that the highlight of the quarter will be the major appointment shopping opportunities of back-to-school and Father's Day, obviously, the Memorial Day shift.  But we think that the consumer is no longer in hiding. But they're being very pragmatic in terms of the way they shop, and the places we've done the best job on price points and giving them compelling merchandise, we've done well. And obviously, our clearance strategy is a major shift in the way we've faced the customer with visitors leaving the store. So we feel cautiously optimistic that back-to-school will be a strong opportunity for us.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you phase out of the catalog, have you guys taken a look at how much you think that's impacting your business online and in-store? And I guess, once we get through the fourth quarter, then that negative drag will dissipate? Is that your expectation?
componenttext: As you phase out of the catalog, have you guys taken a look at how much you think that's impacting your business online and in-store? And I guess, once we get through the fourth quarter, then that negative drag will dissipate? Is that your expectation?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Bob Drbul with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Bob Drbul with Barclays Capital.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, the question I have is you talked about mall traffic being up 1%. Can you talk about how your mall stores did during the second quarter? And what sort of traffic assumptions do you have in your second quarter and full year comp assumptions for the r
componenttext: Mike, the question I have is you talked about mall traffic being up 1%. Can you talk about how your mall stores did during the second quarter? And what sort of traffic assumptions do you have in your second quarter and full year comp assumptions for the remainder of the year?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't actually plan traffic per se. We obviously plan sales, but we track, we have a sampling of malls and off-mall locations that we track every week and try to gauge what the impact of traffic as well purchase conversion is. We've been doing this for
componenttext: We don't actually plan traffic per se. We obviously plan sales, but we track, we have a sampling of malls and off-mall locations that we track every week and try to gauge what the impact of traffic as well purchase conversion is. We've been doing this for a long time, so we're able to look back at the comparable week each year. So we are seeing a shift. Last year on April 30, it was about 4% down in mall traffic. This year is up 1%. So that's our reason for our comments. It's still not where we'd like it to be. Purchase conversion is positive this year. It was negative last year. And off-mall locations continue to do better than on-mall. I think that just reflects the state of the economy and off-mall, closer to home, more merchandising to need than want has been in favor during the recession. So we think that'll moderate going forward, but it's still a factor.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on the second quarter comp guidance, the 2Â½% to 3%, what areas do you think you're being aggressive, if any, in terms of assuming throughout the store to get to that level?
componenttext: And on the second quarter comp guidance, the 2Â½% to 3%, what areas do you think you're being aggressive, if any, in terms of assuming throughout the store to get to that level?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: We never say we're aggressive. We think we're being pragmatic. I would say we feel very good about that Father's Day and early back-to-school period. Our clearance strategy also comes into play. So I think that we feel they have a good plan for the quarte
componenttext: We never say we're aggressive. We think we're being pragmatic. I would say we feel very good about that Father's Day and early back-to-school period. Our clearance strategy also comes into play. So I think that we feel they have a good plan for the quarter. Like everyone else, we'll have to deal with the customer as their sentiment leads them. Center core categories are starting to respond, and that's in support of being our strongest business and obviously modern shoes, handbags, fashion jewelry, those categories are important to us, and we're starting to see some traction.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you just talk about the American Living business at all and how that's trending and your outlook for it?
componenttext: Can you just talk about the American Living business at all and how that's trending and your outlook for it?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think American Living, I think it's our second largest brand and continues to perform well. Obviously, some categories are stronger than others, but we feel that the positioning of American Living and as we've learned, what the customer response to that
componenttext: I think American Living, I think it's our second largest brand and continues to perform well. Obviously, some categories are stronger than others, but we feel that the positioning of American Living and as we've learned, what the customer response to that continues to evolve. And I think it's an important high quality, well-priced category in our classic traditional lifestyle. So no big changes in American living except it keeps being accretive to our performance.

componenttextpreview: The sales guidance for the second quarter of 2Â½% to 3% obviously implies quite a sequential uptick. I guess would you call the wear-now strategy in June the single biggest driver? And how do you plan to drive traffic to the full-priced products versus ha
componenttext: The sales guidance for the second quarter of 2Â½% to 3% obviously implies quite a sequential uptick. I guess would you call the wear-now strategy in June the single biggest driver? And how do you plan to drive traffic to the full-priced products versus having more of a clearance stance last year?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, first of all, if we have more seasonal merchandise and it's how out, the customer actually migrates to the merchandise that's wear-now. Our comments about the clearance strategy is there'll be upturns on the floor throughout the year, and a
componenttext: Well, I think, first of all, if we have more seasonal merchandise and it's how out, the customer actually migrates to the merchandise that's wear-now. Our comments about the clearance strategy is there'll be upturns on the floor throughout the year, and actually one of the reasons it's working well is that the recent markdowns are selling faster than kind of the last phase of the clearance. So we think the clearance strategy will continue to evolve throughout the year and have a benefit throughout the year. But the month of June and the month of January will be the two months to benefit the most from the wear-now incremental inventory on the floor. Again, Father's Day and back-to-school are the two biggest drivers of the season of the quarter, and we feel very good about both of those appointment shopping periods. We also earned a stronger inventory position having built our inventories back up in anticipation of growth in the second half of the year.

componenttext: Mike, could you just share a little bit of perspective on the SEPHORA business, where you have SEPHORA in the stores? What are you seeing in terms of differences between the average transaction value or units per transaction in a SEPHORA transaction versus one without? You might have shared that in the past, but just as reminder on that.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, SEPHORA, obviously has been a tremendous success for us. And I think it speaks well of the concept and how well the customer resonates with the way beauty products are sold, and our customer service in that area is outstanding and exceeding our expe
componenttext:
Well, SEPHORA, obviously has been a tremendous success for us. And I think it speaks well of the concept and how well the customer resonates with the way beauty products are sold, and our customer service in that area is outstanding and exceeding our expectations there as well. Essentially, SEPHORA is not a promotional concept. It's really a concept based on selection and the quality and excitement of the merchandise. It continues be the strongest category in our store. And stores that have SEPHORA tend to do better in overall store sales than stores that have not yet had SEPHORA installed. 
So at this point, we have 193 stores, so we'll be at 230 stores by the end of this year, and we are planning to open 75 stores per year going forward. So SEPHORA is accretive in the sense that it also is the second-most cross-shopped department in our store. So I think those are the elements of SEPHORA. We've learned over the last several years how to open SEPHORA in existing stores and have it be right off the bat successful. We were always very good at it in our new store, but now even existing stores are starting off at a run rate that actually exceeds our original plan. So SEPHORA is a hit and I think it's helped us attract other attractions like Mango and other things to come.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just as a clarification, is there anyway, Mike, are you willing to quantify kind of on average what the comp difference would be in the SEPHORA versus non-SEPHORA store? And then the other question would be on your sort marketing strategy. Given that traf
componenttext: Just as a clarification, is there anyway, Mike, are you willing to quantify kind of on average what the comp difference would be in the SEPHORA versus non-SEPHORA store? And then the other question would be on your sort marketing strategy. Given that traffic is better off-mall than on-mall, and given you have different competitive sets between those two formats or those two shopping venues, where do you see your marketing opportunity, your best return on marketing dollars this year? Is it to take share where traffic has been more challenging and from higher-end competitors, other department stores? Or is it to continue taking share where traffic is stronger and take it from the moderate competitive set?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, we'll take share anywhere we can get it. But clearly, the 18- to 35-year-old segment where 18- to 35-year-old segment, we're under index with the younger customer, so a number of our merchandising initiatives are targeted there and SEP
componenttext: Well, first of all, we'll take share anywhere we can get it. But clearly, the 18- to 35-year-old segment where 18- to 35-year-old segment, we're under index with the younger customer, so a number of our merchandising initiatives are targeted there and SEPHORA being a very useful concept even though it's shopped by all age of customer is accretive to that. We think modern shoes, updated merchandise in center core again is at that underrepresented segment for us. We believe that we have a compelling offer. Essentially, we're well positioned below the more expensive specialty stores and more expensive specialty stores, and that we have the quality and style sufficient to justify the price that we are above the big-box discounters. So I think our marketing "New look. New day. Who knew." is resonating because it's basically the kind of customers that haven't seen what we're doing. They really have no understanding of how it's basically telling the customers, "If you haven't seen what we're doing, you really have no full understanding of how compelling the offer is to JCPenney." So I think we'll continue to do that. We've had a different strategy during the recession than some of our competitors. It was all to build a foundation to be able to launch a more aggressive growth campaign coming out of the recession.

componenttext: Can you update us on what you're seeing on the sourcing cost side and product cost as you look into the back half of the year and into 2011?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Back-up of the year, we feel pretty good confident that we have been able to achieve costing that is not going to give us any heartache on the markup goals we have for the year. Those goods are basically placed at this point. I think if you've been
componenttext: Sure. Back-up of the year, we feel pretty good confident that we have been able to achieve costing that is not going to give us any heartache on the markup goals we have for the year. Those goods are basically placed at this point. I think if you've been reading the press, there's a great deal of concern, in 2011 particularly, for the costing coming out of China and for cotton specifically. I think one of our great strengths is our sourcing expertise and our ability to work with our major manufacturers in Asia. We hope to be able to re-engineer our product to protect our customers in terms of the cost inflation in that area. But it's a concern for the whole industry, and we do believe we have a competitive advantage. But it's a little bit too early to really tell if there'll be an impact on our costing.

componenttext: And then I know you've increased your contemporary offerings and SEPHORA has helped that. I know you just mentioned that you're under indexed in the 18 to 35 age. Have you seen success in these initiatives in attracting a younger customer to JCP in terms of a decline in average age?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, as a matter of fact, one of our biggest opportunities in jcp.com is that we've been under indexed with the younger customer online. Actually we have a higher index of younger customers in the store than we do online which is kind of intuitive. So we
componenttext: Yes, as a matter of fact, one of our biggest opportunities in jcp.com is that we've been under indexed with the younger customer online. Actually we have a higher index of younger customers in the store than we do online which is kind of intuitive. So we think part of that is improved messaging and more digital marketing and community marketing. I think it's one of the areas where we lead in mobile, community and other digital assets. So as I've mentioned on a number of occasions, we've invested very heavily in the new environment of portable devices, mobile and other ways of reaching that younger customer. So we think those investments are going to continue to pay off, and we believe that the Internet business as well as how we market our stores and Catalog business digitally will continue to be a bigger part of our marketing.

componenttext: Mike, I was just curious, usually you sit on the Federal Reserve board meeting the day before you report earnings. Just wondering, any pearls of wisdom or any commentary you can share for us coming out of that?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think Richard Fisher, the President of the Dallas Fed spoke publicly yesterday and couple things that he covered were in the press this morning. One was that the recession, being the worst economic downturn since the Great Depression, was going to
componenttext: Well, I think Richard Fisher, the President of the Dallas Fed spoke publicly yesterday and couple things that he covered were in the press this morning. One was that the recession, being the worst economic downturn since the Great Depression, was going to take longer to get out of than probably most people had originally anticipated. Second, the China cost pressures would start to be an issue, and there was as much concern about low inflation at this point as there is I guess for high inflation. So I think the tone of it is for an extended period of time, it's going to be a slow climb out of the existing economic reality.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't want to make it sound too complicated, but essentially, some customers that were getting the Big Book were entering their order online. So as we basically took away the Big Book, we took away the ordering online volume that, that would've created.
componenttext: I don't want to make it sound too complicated, but essentially, some customers that were getting the Big Book were entering their order online. So as we basically took away the Big Book, we took away the ordering online volume that, that would've created. And we really don't have a good number for the whole year because so far we've only passed one Big Book. But it's having a drag on kind of the way we report online volume. It'll all work itself out as essentially we get past the third Big Book at the end of the year. We don't see it as a material impact in terms of the way we go to market with catalog, Internet or stores, but it does have kind of a strange impact on how we report dot-com in the near term.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, I'd have to disagree with your assertion, and that is that when I said the apparel categories were up double digit, I wouldn't call those slim, okay?
componenttext: First, I'd have to disagree with your assertion, and that is that when I said the apparel categories were up double digit, I wouldn't call those slim, okay?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 14, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to argue with you. But I'm saying the barrel [ph] business is the biggest part of our business. And it's up double digits. The two things that are dragging it down at the moment are the shift in the Big Book Catalog business and the sluggish
componenttext: I'm not going to argue with you. But I'm saying the barrel [ph] business is the biggest part of our business. And it's up double digits. The two things that are dragging it down at the moment are the shift in the Big Book Catalog business and the sluggishness particularly of big-ticket Home. So the answer to the last part of your question is what do we see going forward, we still think the dot-com business is a major source of growth, perhaps double-digit in the second half of the year overall. And the reason we believe that is we believe as more of our store shoppers see the alignment of inventory, same items online as we have in the store, which didn't used to be the case, that they'll start to cross-shop more and it'll be accretive to not only dot-com business but also the overall spend as the customer finds easier to shop at JCPenney.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the JCPenney Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ms. Kristin Hays, Vice President, Investor Relations. Ms. Hays, you may begin.
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the JCPenney Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ms. Kristin Hays, Vice President, Investor Relations. Ms. Hays, you may begin.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jackie, and thank you, all, for joining us on the call this morning to review JCPenney's second quarter earnings. Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning
componenttext:
Thank you, Jackie, and thank you, all, for joining us on the call this morning to review JCPenney's second quarter earnings. 
Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, which reflects the company's current view of future events and financial performance. The words expect, plan, anticipate, believe and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements. 
Any such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, and the company's of future results of operation could differ materially from historical results or current expectations. For more details on these risks, please refer to the company's Form 10-K and other SEC filings. 
Also, please note that no portion of this call may be rebroadcast in any form without the prior written consent of JCPenney. Replay of today's webcast will be available for 90 days. For those listening after August 13, 2010, please note that this recording will not be updated, and it is possible that the information discussed will no longer be current. 
On this morning's call, we will have two speakers: First, Bob Cavanaugh, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; followed by Mike Ullman, JCPenney's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Bob.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kristin, and good morning, everyone. I will be speaking with you this morning about our financial results in the second quarter. Mike will then provide additional color around our results and an update on our strategic initiatives. This morning,
componenttext:
Thanks, Kristin, and good morning, everyone. I will be speaking with you this morning about our financial results in the second quarter. Mike will then provide additional color around our results and an update on our strategic initiatives. 
This morning, we reported second quarter earnings of $0.06 per share compared to break-even results last year and within our guidance of $0.05 to $0.08 per share, including the $0.05 impact for bond premiums incurred in connection with the company's debt tender offer completed in May. Our second quarter results demonstrate our commitment to operational flexibility and delivering improved profitability. Sales for the quarter were challenged by the company's performance in July, and in particular, were impacted by two non-comparable factors that Mike will discuss in a few minutes. 
All other financial and operational metrics exceeded plan for the quarter, and first half earnings were $0.31 per share compared with $0.11 per share in last year's first half. Gross margin exceeded plan and improved 90 basis points to a historic peak for the second quarter of 39.4%, primarily due to our ability to control unit cost through strong sourcing relationships and through more profitable sales of clearance merchandise during the quarter under our Red Zone clearance strategy. Also contributing to gross margin was exceptional sell-through of wear now merchandise, combined with year-over-year shrinkage improvement attributable to our shrinkage reduction initiatives. 
Our team continues to exhibit discipline in managing our operating expenses across the entire organization, as SG&A came in much better than guidance, up only 2.5% over last year. The increase in SG&A dollars is partially attributable to expenses related to new stores and the continued rollout of the Sephora inside JCPenney boutiques. These increases were partially offset by a reduction in the incentive compensation accrual. 
Operating income for the quarter was up 41.8% to $95 million compared with $67 million last year. As noted in the release, if we exclude the impact of the non-cash qualified pension plan expense from both this year's and last year's second quarter, adjusted operating income increased 7.1%. 
Total operating expenses were relatively flat to last year, increasing 20 basis points as a percentage of sales. Interest expense for the quarter was $57 million compared to $68 million in the prior year. The company also incurred approximately $20 million in additional expenses, primarily of bond premiums paid in connection with the debt tender offer I referred to earlier. 
The effective tax rate for the quarter was 22.2% and reflected favorable adjustments to the company's state income taxes, and we had approximately 238 million average diluted shares for the quarter.  For the bottom line, net income was $14 million or $0.06 per share for the quarter. 
Moving on to our financial condition. We remain in a strong financial position, with continued flexibility to support the key components of our growth initiatives over the long-range plan. As of July 31, the company had cash and cash equivalents of approximately $2 billion. Year to date, our free cash flow is on plan. Taking into consideration our free cash flow position and the financing transactions noted in the release, we ended the first half with $300 million less cash when compared to last year's first half, and we ended the quarter with $300 million less debt or long-term debt of approximately $3.1 billion compared to $3.4 billion last year. 
Capital expenditures for the quarter were approximately $113 million compared with $148 million in last year's second quarter. We continue to reinvest in our existing stores and expect full year capital expenditures to be approximately $500 million. This includes 23 major store renovations, renovations associated with the addition of 76 Sephora inside JCPenney boutiques and store enhancements to support merchandise sets for Liz Claiborne and MNG by Mango. 
Turning now to guidance for the third quarter. We expect comparable store sales to be up 2% to 3% for the third quarter. Total sales will be up approximately 100 basis points less than comparable store sales due to the expected negative impact from the discontinuation of our Big Book catalogs. We expect gross margins as a percent of sales to decline modestly during the quarter, which is unchanged from our original plan. 
SG&A expenses are expected to be up approximately 2% compared to last year's third quarter. Depreciation and amortization should be approximately $129 million, net interest expense of about $57 million and we expect a tax rate of approximately 38%. We currently anticipate about 238 million average diluted shares, including about 2 million common stock equivalents. 
For the third quarter, we expect earnings to be in the range of approximately $0.16 to $0.20 per share. And for the full year, we now expect earnings be in the range of $1.40 and $1.50 per share, as we are taking a relatively conservative approach to the economic climate and especially the moderate consumer. 
In summary, with the disciplined approach to our business, we continue to have the financial flexibility to support the strategies of our long-range plan. This is enabling JCPenney to strengthen both competitively and financially and position our business for long-term success. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Mike Ullman for more color on the company's performance and outlook.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob, and good morning, everyone. We delivered on our plan for the bulk of the period, resulting in sales increases across several core merchandise categories and regular promotional prices that were driven by the initiatives we outlined in our
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob, and good morning, everyone. We delivered on our plan for the bulk of the period, resulting in sales increases across several core merchandise categories and regular promotional prices that were driven by the initiatives we outlined in our Analyst Meeting in April. Our core apparel lines have performed very well and we hit our internal sales plans for the quarter in all of our key categories. We also delivered record gross margins and further strengthened our financial position during the period. 
Comparable store sales were positive for the second consecutive quarter, increasing approximately 1% from last year. We focused on increasing a proportion of wear now and season merchandise in our mix, enabling us to drive profitable sales at regular and promotional prices. And we were able to pull forward major deliveries to meet the demand, as we were selling through the merchandise earlier than anticipated. As a result, we are entering the third quarter in a very clean forward-looking inventory position. 
Also, as Bob mentioned, we opened 22 additional Sephora inside JCPenney shop within the store locations to bring our total to date to 215, which will increase to 232 by the end of the year. The sales trend of stores that have Sephora inside  JCPenney are consistently performing 150 basis points higher than stores that do not yet have the concept. And the sales productivity of Sephora space in the store is 3x the average of the overall store.  Due to the success of this concept, we'll continue to open approximately 75 Sephora locations for the year. 
To give you a sense of the sales by category, our Women's business continues to be strong, driven by the success of wear now apparel. As you know, we're up against very strong comps from last year when our Women's Apparel business was the industry leading performer during the downturn. And we expect our Women's businesses to be even stronger in the second half of the year, with the addition of Liz Claiborne and MNG by Mango, as well as the ongoing positive changes were making across our Apparel, Accessories, Shoes and Fine Jewelry businesses. 
Our new Liz Claiborne merchandise began arriving at the beginning of this month, and the response from customers has been overwhelmingly positive. The Liz brand is already beating our expectations, and the official marketing launch of the brand is until mid-September. 
The 77 MNG by Mango shops will open next week, as well as on jcp.com. We will reach a total of 600 stores by the end of next fall. There are really only truly five fast fashion retailers in the world: Zara, Uniqlo, Forever 21, H&M and Mango, and none of them have a department store presence in the U.S. With approximately 1,500 square feet of a shop within a shop, JCPenney will be the only department store offering true fast fashion, and the merchandise looks great and the shop environment will be compelling. 
Our first Call It Spring by ALDO Group's shop within a shop will open in September in our Manhattan store. Call It Spring will offer our customers an extensive collection of over 300 styles of up-to-the-minute, on-trend footwear and accessories, all at compelling prices. Again, we're the only department store retailer carrying ALDO-branded product outside their own specialty stores, and we're rapidly rolling this out to 600 stores over the next 12 months. 
Our Men's divisions had the strongest categories in the quarter, up 5.5%. We had an outstanding Father's Day and continuing to experience a great trend in our men's business. Sportswear, for example, is up 9%. Our success is a direct result of changes we made in adding assortment, sharpening our price points and the compelling type of floor presentations. 
We're also starting to see signs of life in our Home business through the new initiatives being put in place by John Tighe, our new GMM of Home. Specifically, we're seeing traction in our Soft Home business, with particular strength in the more affordable items. Our Furniture and Window Covering businesses, however, remain tough as a result of protracted housing slump, and improvement in these areas will be a longer-term proposition. 
In terms of the Children's businesses, the changes we're making are evident in our back-to-school offerings. While still early, we're very pleased with the performance of our just-launched brands of Uproar and Supergirl by Nastia, and the ongoing strength of our relatively new brands, including Olsenboye by Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, and Ryan Sheckler's RS by Sheckler brand. This, coupled with the breadth of our operating and core merchandise that kids need every year, including a terrific down selection of school uniforms, positions us well to once again be the leading back-to-school destination. 
However, we do expect the peak back-to-school selling period to be very close to school openings around the country. The timing of shopping malls will of course be tied closely to the tax-free events that are being held in a number of states to support back-to-school shopping. 
Overall, we have seen great strength in our Kid's businesses. As we continue to execute our growth strategy, which during the quarter, drove positive sales; our focus of driving greater value to our customers by offering sharp price points in private label brand; as well as increasing sales of select national brands, with great brand line like Carter's, has really moved the needle in establishing JCPenney as a destination for moms. In the second quarter, Carter's was up almost 30% over last year's quarter, while our private brand, Okie Dokie, also had a great sales increase. 
Our successful internet remains the largest general merchandising site, exceeding 1.5 billion per year. As you know, we made the decision to exit the Big Book catalog business at the beginning of the year. As it turns out, many of the former Big Book customers entered their orders online in the past, the loss of that sales volume this year had a negative effect on our overall internet trend and overall comp. Despite this non-comparable effect, jcp.com was up 4.1% for the quarter, fueled primarily by double-digit rises in all apparel categories. 
Contributing to our strong .com increases in July was at the introduction of Guided Navigation, which quickly directs customers to the right products within a few clicks. July was our first full month that it was available across all of our online categories, which led to a 22% lift in the average order value for the month. 
To give you some highlights for the quarter. All regions year-to-date have positive comp increases, all five regions, with the Southeast being up the most on a spring season basis. Overall transactions were up 5.9% and units per transaction were up 2.3% for the quarter. AUR was down slightly as planned. 
Due to our leading product development and sourcing organization and the long-term relationships we have with our overseas suppliers, our cost of goods has declined, which allowed us to pass the savings on to our customers. So while our overall average AUR is down slightly, we planned it that way. In order to provide our customers with the value they're looking for, we're hurting our gross merges. This AUR strategy worked. Throughout the quarter, our private brands continue to outperform national brands by approximately 400 basis points in sales trend, and we experienced an even larger improvement of approximately 800 basis points in private brand gross profit higher than national brands. 
Clearance AUR through our Red Zone clearance program was up 3.9%. We began this program at the beginning of the season, and its benefits are very clear. Our merchants can now accelerate the markdown on slow-selling merchandise on a more timely basis and have it available for sale in the apparel department locations throughout the store. This approach improves our flow of new fresh merchandise sold at regular and promotional price points, while maintaining a consistent presentation of clearance merchandise, which is moving out in a faster rate and more profitably. 
Yet, another key initiative is that the ramp up of our JCP Rewards program, which now reached to 8 million members by the end of the quarter. JCP Rewards customers visit JCPenney stores about 2x more per year than non-rewards customers and spend approximately $100 more per year. For the back half of the year, we'll be launching some major program enhancements that will continue to drive top line sales for us with this very important and very loyal customer. 
Total inventory at the close of the quarter was up approximately 7% over last year. This includes customer-facing inventory in stores and is approximately 5%, in line with the company's initial plan for sales to improve sequentially in the second half of the year. While the inventory is up compared to our updated sales guidance for the third quarter, we're very comfortable with the levels that includes private brand merchandise that we pulled forward to avoid overseas disruptions that may have negatively impacted our future deliveries during the back half. And we're holding this merchandise in our logistics facilities until its planned set dates. 
Additionally, a portion of the inventory increase includes the company's in-transit merchandise from our international sourcing organization in support of JCPenney's growth initiatives, including a higher sales mix of our private brands and the launch of Liz Claiborne in our stores and on jcp.com. And remember, we are now sourcing the Liz Claiborne brand ourselves, so the inventory ownership there is reflected earlier in the cycle. Again, we're very comfortable with our levels of merchandise. 
Mall traffic was up throughout the quarter, and that was mirrored in JCP store traffic as well. As has consistently been the trend, traffic in our off-mall stores is about 350 basis points higher than our mall-based stores. As we have mentioned, offsetting our positive sales trend at the end of the quarter were the impact of two non-comparable items that distorted our true operating performance for the balance for the balance of the year. So I want to call them out to you now, so it don't impact your point of view about the vibrancy of our business or your perception of our competitor's market share performance. 
The discontinuation of the Big Book catalog will impact total sales this year. This is particularly true in July, as we're up against two Big Book catalog drops from last year. This resulted in a 200 basis point hit to our total sales in July and 160 basis points for the quarter. 
The other non-comparable is our Red Zone clearance strategy transition, which allows us to move our clearance in a much smoother cadence throughout the year versus our previous clearance strategy of having large clearance downloads at the end of each season. Two of the largest downloads occurred at the end of July, and again, mid-February. So with that, we're up against our first big clearance download this last week of July. I should note that while the July clearance wasn't a surprise to us, as we knew it was coming, in retrospect, we could've handled it better as we ultimately gained back much of our comp sales increase that we earned throughout the quarter during that final week of July. 
Overall, we're very pleased with our Red Zone clearance program. It's working, and we're selling our clearance merchandise earlier in the cycle and more profitably. That said, one week is a brief moment in time, given what we've learned from it, we'll work to mitigate short-term impact in the future. And so overall, we're encouraged about where our business is heading and we're it managing well, as you can tell from our net and operating income results. 
So in conclusion, Bob shared with your guidance for the third quarter and the balance of the year. What it reflects is a conservative approach to what continues to be an uncertain consumer climate, particularly for the moderate consumer. Having said that, we're on a journey to fundamentally transform JCPenney from a traditional catalog-based department store to a retail destination for discovering great style at compelling prices. And we're on track with our plans to do just that. We're creating sustainable enterprise where customers receive attentive personalized service and inspired by our merchandise offerings, with engaged associates who choose to invest their careers toward us, and we will maintain a strong financial position even during the tough economic climate. 
As you know, growing top line sales is an important objective of our long-range plan. We have identified merchandise growth opportunities that will entice current customers to visit more frequently, engage and attract new and younger customers, and increase in customer spending overall. We have a compelling merchandise offering for our customers, with half of our business in industry-leading private brands and the other half in the best of national exclusive brands. 
As we continue to invest and power up our private brands, we expect they will continue grow at a faster rate than national brands and to continue providing great value to our customers and higher profitability for us. And we're bringing innovation to what we offer to our customers. JCPenney continues to implement game-changing merchandise growth concepts that will not only drive higher sales per square foot but help us establish JCPenney as a style destination. Sephora inside JCPenney, Liz Claiborne, MNG by Mango, Call It Spring by ALDO are clear examples of this. 
jcp.com is the leading general merchandise site on the internet, and it continues to grow. We have done a lot of the hard work during the recession to overhaul our entire digital platform. Customers are changing the way they interact through technology, and the retail competitive landscape, especially online, has changed even more dramatically. We're on the forefront of the changes. Our investment in the future retailing has competitive advantage and one that's not easily replicated. 
The actions we're taking are the right ones for our customers, our associates and our investors. We are intently focused on growing the top line. Maintaining our margins while maintaining a strong financial position allows us to pursue our growth initiatives. While we're committed to delivering progress every quarter, our overall objective of our journey is to build a long-term sustainable franchise and shareholder value. 
With that, we'll open the line to your questions.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: We identified 14 growth initiatives that we began the year getting our store and merchandising executives focused on building for the fall season. We've been tracking those ever since, and I think something like 11 of the 14 are at the planned levels or a
componenttext: We identified 14 growth initiatives that we began the year getting our store and merchandising executives focused on building for the fall season. We've been tracking those ever since, and I think something like 11 of the 14 are at the planned levels or above. So we feel very confident that what we've invested in, in terms of inventory and our focus at the store level on those initiatives that we can deliver the comps. However, conservative they may seem, with the overall external environment, we feel very good that we can create that business from those investments.

componenttextpreview: As I said in my prepared remarks, we're quite gratified. Obviously, we have Liz & Co. still on the floor and being cleared. But I would say from our store checks, everybody is very enthusiastic about the response.
componenttext: As I said in my prepared remarks, we're quite gratified. Obviously, we have Liz & Co. still on the floor and being cleared. But I would say from our store checks, everybody is very enthusiastic about the response.
