headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said in my prepared remarks, I think we were a bit maybe unprepared or not properly prepared for the big spikes that we experienced at the end of July of last year. We were unable to offset those within the month. Having said that, the whole st
componenttext: Well, as I said in my prepared remarks, I think we were a bit maybe unprepared or not properly prepared for the big spikes that we experienced at the end of July of last year. We were unable to offset those within the month. Having said that, the whole strategy is build around clearing the merchandise on a more profitable basis. So it hasn't deterred us from our overall objective. On an annual basis or 12-month basis, we feel we'll hit our objective on the bottom line. It just doesn't show up well in terms of the cadence month-to-month. But as I said, we're going to look for ways to mitigate the effect on the next two that we face.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: With the off-mall stores outperforming, 350 basis points higher than on-mall, when might we see you reaccelerate your off-mall rollout?
componenttext: With the off-mall stores outperforming, 350 basis points higher than on-mall, when might we see you reaccelerate your off-mall rollout?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we'll be announcing some additional off-mall shortly. We're not going to go chase deals in the commercial real estate environment that is not robust. But if there are opportunities, we'll obviously pursue them. Quite honestly, we're kind of gratifie
componenttext: Well, we'll be announcing some additional off-mall shortly. We're not going to go chase deals in the commercial real estate environment that is not robust. But if there are opportunities, we'll obviously pursue them. Quite honestly, we're kind of gratified that a lot of the new stores we opened last three or four years are performing very well. We are very concerned about the housing areas that didn't fully develop, that we might see a protracted shortfall on those stores. But we focused on them in the last several years, and they're performing at or above the store trends.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Adrianne Shapira of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Adrianne Shapira of Goldman Sachs.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, on the inventory, could you help us share your comfort in terms of inventory up 7%. And if you could give us some color, how much of it was pull-forward merchandise and where you like to see inventory levels at the end of the third quarter?
componenttext: Mike, on the inventory, could you help us share your comfort in terms of inventory up 7%. And if you could give us some color, how much of it was pull-forward merchandise and where you like to see inventory levels at the end of the third quarter?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, essentially, we're right on plan at the end of the July. And as we said, we plan to bring in some of the merchandise earlier because we want to be sure, given the container shortages and the various things that were going on in Asia, that some of ou
componenttext: Well, essentially, we're right on plan at the end of the July. And as we said, we plan to bring in some of the merchandise earlier because we want to be sure, given the container shortages and the various things that were going on in Asia, that some of our new launches were adversely affected by that. So one part of our comfort is that the additional inventories is essentially invested in the growth categories that we plan at the beginning of the year, Claiborne being a big one. And as I mentioned, we now own the Claiborne merchandise all the way back to the source, were in the past, which is not comfortable, because Liz & Co. merchandise was produced through Claiborne, and we owned it only at point of entry in the U.S. So that's a bit non-comparable. So in terms of right now, as we forecast out the fall season, as Bob mentioned, we're a bit more concerned than we would've been at the beginning of the year about the consumer environment. So we're going to be looking very carefully at revising some aspects of our sales and inventory toward the rest of the year, but we don't see any major issue at this point.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: So beyond the third quarter in terms of heading into the fourth, give us a sense in terms of, as you said, a bit more cautious, how we should be thinking about sales and inventory levels as we enter the fourth quarter?
componenttext: So beyond the third quarter in terms of heading into the fourth, give us a sense in terms of, as you said, a bit more cautious, how we should be thinking about sales and inventory levels as we enter the fourth quarter?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think most retailers, as they thought about 2010 at the beginning of the year, we're very optimistic that they were up against very soft numbers and it would be easy to be up against those comps. But I think all of us have found that the relative
componenttext: Well, I think most retailers, as they thought about 2010 at the beginning of the year, we're very optimistic that they were up against very soft numbers and it would be easy to be up against those comps. But I think all of us have found that the relative slowing down of the consumer economy in the last three or four months. So I think most retailers, as what we heard in Asia, we were there for a week a couple weeks ago talking with all the suppliers, that they're across the board more caution in terms of forward inventories. So I think it's prudent for us to also be cautious. Having said that, our cycle times are shorter than our competition. Our relationship with suppliers is more long-standing, and certainly, they're very attentive to our needs. So we think we'll be in a decent shape to react.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just shifting gears to the margin, you said peak gross margins, well, it sounds in the third quarter, we should be looking for gross margins to be down if inventory is in good shape, kind of help us think about why then gross margins will be down
componenttext: And then just shifting gears to the margin, you said peak gross margins, well, it sounds in the third quarter, we should be looking for gross margins to be down if inventory is in good shape, kind of help us think about why then gross margins will be down?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Big Book catalog, well, we can give you all the reasons why we should get out of the business. One aspect that was good is that actually it was fairly high margin business. This was the most conservative product we had. And frankly, just looking at
componenttext: Well, Big Book catalog, well, we can give you all the reasons why we should get out of the business. One aspect that was good is that actually it was fairly high margin business. This was the most conservative product we had. And frankly, just looking at the three books themselves, they were quite profitable. The problem is, over time, with higher printing costs and higher postage and the customer migrating more and more to online, at some point, they're going to be a major drag. So we've chosen to take the hit this year, and it will have a detrimental effect on margins in the third quarter and fourth quarter.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then when will look beyond the back half in terms of margins, help us think about how we should be thinking about what the right level, especially maybe give some of your insight into inflation pressures given your extensive sourcing capabilities?
componenttext: And then when will look beyond the back half in terms of margins, help us think about how we should be thinking about what the right level, especially maybe give some of your insight into inflation pressures given your extensive sourcing capabilities?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think anybody that spend any time looking at the situation, particularly in China for 2011, would tell you there's a lot of headwinds, particularly the cost of cotton, labor, shortages, believe it or not, social costs, minimum wages. And just the
componenttext: Well, I think anybody that spend any time looking at the situation, particularly in China for 2011, would tell you there's a lot of headwinds, particularly the cost of cotton, labor, shortages, believe it or not, social costs, minimum wages. And just the overall domestic environment in China is such that there's much more domestic demand, which is putting pressure on costing overall, particularly for apparel. Fortunately, we started to diversify our sourcing locations four or five years ago. So we have a balance of sourcing across Vietnam, Bangladesh, Indonesia, Turkey, India. So we probably have less of an impact from China by itself. The cotton crop upcoming looks like it's stronger than the last. So I think any body who thinks that they're going to get cost improvement in '11 probably hasn't studied the facts. I think our view is that our cost impact will be less than our key competitors, that it will be naive to think that we're going to shielded completely. The last time there was an apparel cost increases, that was probably in 1992. So consumers gotten the benefit as the retailers, the benefit of the deflationary category, if there is such a thing as a benefit of a declining retail. But we don't see that continuing in 2011.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: And any thoughts in terms of passing that on?
componenttext: And any thoughts in terms of passing that on?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the broad line retail sector has the lowest pricing power of any sector in the economy according to the studies we've seen. So we expect to have to run our business more effectively to be able to shield the customer from those cost increases.
componenttext: I think the broad line retail sector has the lowest pricing power of any sector in the economy according to the studies we've seen. So we expect to have to run our business more effectively to be able to shield the customer from those cost increases.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Dana Telsey of Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Dana Telsey of Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a little update on the Home area, what you're seeing there and plans for the future? And then as you think about the new merchandising initiatives, whether it's Liz Claiborne, whether it's Mango, how do you look at their impact on the gros
componenttext: Can you give us a little update on the Home area, what you're seeing there and plans for the future? And then as you think about the new merchandising initiatives, whether it's Liz Claiborne, whether it's Mango, how do you look at their impact on the gross margin?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: For the Home business, I think John and his team have done a very good job of what I consider to be getting the floor organized in more logical manner. The introductions of some new innovation like the Pure Perfection towel, which has gone very well and t
componenttext: For the Home business, I think John and his team have done a very good job of what I consider to be getting the floor organized in more logical manner. The introductions of some new innovation like the Pure Perfection towel, which has gone very well and the realignment of our Bedding business. So the Soft Home part of our business is starting to respond. Stores have been very enthusiastic about what they saw for fall at our recent store managers' meeting, one of the most well-received sessions with the powering up of big, bold statements in Soft Home. As I mentioned in my prepared remarks, we think the big ticket, Furniture and Window Covering business, will respond more slowly just by the reality of the housing slump being protracted beyond what was originally envisioned. But we think it's going to take another six months or so to see the full benefit of the changes that they're making. But we're starting to see signs of life and certainly, we always look to our sales associates because of they're the best customers we have and the best authority on how we're doing, and they feel very good about what they see on the floor. As to the margin impact on Liz and MNG by Mango, Liz has actually a very favorable product margin impact to us because part of our deal with the Liz Claiborne Corporation [Liz Claiborne Inc.] was for us to produce their merchandise, which gave us a 500 or 600 basis points improvement in gross margin profit even on the comparable sales. So the fact that it's also across more categories and we expect to grow it aggressively over the next five years, we think it's nothing but a positive to GP. MNG by Mango, frankly, is not driven on the basis of being a great GP conservator, but it is a contemporary fashion attraction, and that we'll only have in 77 stores this fall. We'll learn as we go. They have proven in their business, in the core Mango business, that they can turn the merchandise profitably. Until we obviously experience that with our customers, we won't have as much information that they currently have. They're very enthusiastic about going from 12 stores in the U.S. to 600 in a little over a year. So this is a big opportunity for them as well as we'll market aggressively one of the most successful fashion concepts in the world. So I think that the department store executives were candid. They would tell you that probably $20 billion to $30 billion of volumes come out of the department stores via the fashion retailers ramping up a very successful business model. And we think it's a real coup to have one of those residents at the entrance of our biggest stores.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Chuck Grom of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Chuck Grom of JPMorgan.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, if you can help us connect the dots on your top line outlook, I believe you said in your prepared remarks that you're more concerned on the consumer today than you were in the spring and you're going against tougher compares in the back half, yet yo
componenttext: Mike, if you can help us connect the dots on your top line outlook, I believe you said in your prepared remarks that you're more concerned on the consumer today than you were in the spring and you're going against tougher compares in the back half, yet you're guiding to comps up 2% to 3%, about what you did in the first half of the year. I guess, can you just help us get a better understanding of how much of a lift you're baking in from either the 14 initiatives that you spoke to earlier or the Liz and MNG new brand launches?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, virtually all of the comp increase in the back half was fueling up our growth initiatives. If you look at the Liz Claiborne ramp up, there are 77 more supplier. If you look at our JCP Rewards increases, if you look at what we have plan
componenttext: Well, first of all, virtually all of the comp increase in the back half was fueling up our growth initiatives. If you look at the Liz Claiborne ramp up, there are 77 more supplier. If you look at our JCP Rewards increases, if you look at what we have planned in terms of guided navigation on dot com, our center core merchandising should have -- whether it be the Tops business across all businesses or the Accessories category, modern shoes, we've basically identified the growth categories at the beginning of the year and we knew most of those we're not going to be accretive in the first half. Although, what we try to say is as we thought about the year, we aren't going to look to the consumer economy to help us at all in 2010. Now we think there might be a slight drag on the consumer portion of this and we have to create not only the -- plus, we have to make it work harder to get to our comps. So I think anybody who's objective about the current environment saw a gradual slowing of the economy. I think, to be candid, the upper quartile customer never ran out of money. And those that catered to that customer had been smart in terms of looking at the merchandise they have on the floor and offering more value in a sector that really wasn't values-oriented in the past. I think the bottom quartile is obviously families are getting by, by taking care of the needs of their family. They don't have much flexibility beyond that. The middle two quartiles, which are our core customers, they've had the brunt of essentially the effect of the job situation. The country basically hasn't re-employed a worker at this point. There's new entrants to the workforce, 125,000 a month. It's larger than average job increases per month. So to be realistic, consumer constriction credit, the job loss situation and the protracted housing situation, this had the biggest impact on the middle income consumer. So as a store that's proud to be aligned with our consumer, we have to recognize that they have issues. And we obviously want to help them get through this by offering great value, but our customer tends to be more urban, more ethnic and more impacted by the economy than many others in the overall retail landscape.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: So is it safe to assume that maybe one to two points of a conflict from some of these new brand launches if I look at your guidance relative to what you did in the first half?
componenttext: So is it safe to assume that maybe one to two points of a conflict from some of these new brand launches if I look at your guidance relative to what you did in the first half?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say more than that. I would say virtually all of our comp will be considered to be on these initiatives.
componenttext: I would say more than that. I would say virtually all of our comp will be considered to be on these initiatives.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then can you shed any light on how you think the quarter will progress in terms of month-to-month cadence? You got easy comparing here in August and it gets a little bit harder. And any color on August trends? We're a couple weeks in so far.
componenttext: And then can you shed any light on how you think the quarter will progress in terms of month-to-month cadence? You got easy comparing here in August and it gets a little bit harder. And any color on August trends? We're a couple weeks in so far.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's fairly even across the three months, to be honest. I think the back-to-school is the hardest to read. The four-week August, for us, for example, our best business right now happens to be in Texas because school starts earlier. So we look at T
componenttext: I think it's fairly even across the three months, to be honest. I think the back-to-school is the hardest to read. The four-week August, for us, for example, our best business right now happens to be in Texas because school starts earlier. So we look at Texas, extrapolate across the country, we'd be very, very satisfied with back-to-school. Having said that, it's been the hottest in 60 years this summer, so the Bottoms business has not been great. The Coat business has not been great. So if it starts to be more seasonal in temperature and people start feel more animal spirits about getting back-to-school pick, I think we'll feel more optimistic. But right now, we're treating August as if it's on the trend for the quarter.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the Big Book, you said 160 bps in the quarter, I didn't recall you quantifying that in the first quarter. And then I guess maybe a question for Bob would be, I think the last time you reported catalog costs, at least in my model, was in 2005 a
componenttext: In terms of the Big Book, you said 160 bps in the quarter, I didn't recall you quantifying that in the first quarter. And then I guess maybe a question for Bob would be, I think the last time you reported catalog costs, at least in my model, was in 2005 and we had them at around $255 million. And I know not all that is for the Big Book, but you speak to the hit from not doing the Big Book. Could you quantify the expense benefit you're getting from not printing and distributing that book?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a complicated question, Chuck because we've stopped dropping the Big Books, there's three per year. We stopped at B in the spring season. But the impact in the first quarter wasn't as great because the Book lasts for four, five months so the biggest
componenttext: It's a complicated question, Chuck because we've stopped dropping the Big Books, there's three per year. We stopped at B in the spring season. But the impact in the first quarter wasn't as great because the Book lasts for four, five months so the biggest impact of it actually ended up in the second quarter. And we probably didn't fully realize how much of it was online entry in the past until we started looking at it more closely and realize that a lot of that catalog business that customers not seeing this merchandise in a book this year, so she couldn't order it. It wasn't there. The books themselves, as I said, they probably, at one point, average over $400 million of our volume per book. And it gradually has been declining towards about half of that today. So the costing is an interactive process of re-engineering our infrastructure, which we started two years ago by aligning merchandising into one organization and marketing and immediate planning into one organization. So today, it's blended. It's a little hard to identify which part today would have been allocated toward the Big Book. But gradually, our Catalog business is declining and our Direct Mail and our Guided Media to allow people to shop online is increasing. So the point I made was that printing a 600- or 800-page document as opposed to the increases in the printing costs, not to mention the ecological impact of producing this thing. We decided it was time to take the hit and while it's detrimental to this year, we think it's the right thing to do. And we'll reinvest a lot of that media in the Direct Mail and things that are related more to dot com.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Michelle Clark of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Michelle Clark of Morgan Stanley.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's actually Chris Cuomo here filling in for Michelle. I just had a question for the SG&A guidance. Looks like you're guiding up 2% per sales around 2%. Just could you talk about how we should think about the relationship between SG&A and sales go forwar
componenttext: It's actually Chris Cuomo here filling in for Michelle. I just had a question for the SG&A guidance. Looks like you're guiding up 2% per sales around 2%. Just could you talk about how we should think about the relationship between SG&A and sales go forward? And is there is any sort of one-time item from an SG&A perspective in the third quarter?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: SG&A is a little bit complicated because of last year. We didn't have salary increases and this year, obviously, we're up against that. And we also moved our salary increases from August 1 for most associates to May 1. So the impact conception is a little
componenttext: SG&A is a little bit complicated because of last year. We didn't have salary increases and this year, obviously, we're up against that. And we also moved our salary increases from August 1 for most associates to May 1. So the impact conception is a little bit higher in the second quarter incrementally than it would be in the third. Having said that, we also have new stores in the mix, support locations in the mix and benefit costs and so forth. So we don't think there's any big surprises in SG&A. But clearly, we keep lowering the comp expectation, obviously, puts more and more pressure on SG&A. And we'll take a hard look at expense in the second half to be sure we're expensed properly.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, in the past, I think you've talked about your customer service scores, and I think you called out the highly satisfied customer and next you were tracking in the low 60s. I think you have mentioned that in your Analyst Day. I was just wondering if y
componenttext: Mike, in the past, I think you've talked about your customer service scores, and I think you called out the highly satisfied customer and next you were tracking in the low 60s. I think you have mentioned that in your Analyst Day. I was just wondering if you could update us in terms of how you are trending in terms of the customer service scores and that highly satisfied index?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd be happy to. We're very proud of our customer service, and obviously, American Express called in number one two years in a row for stores. It's great, kudos to our people. We are tracking in the low 60s in terms of the overall highly satisfied. Our go
componenttext: I'd be happy to. We're very proud of our customer service, and obviously, American Express called in number one two years in a row for stores. It's great, kudos to our people. We are tracking in the low 60s in terms of the overall highly satisfied. Our goal for the year is to try to get 65 by the end of the year. We're on track to do that. We've got a couple points of improvements since the beginning of the year. It gets harder because, obviously, as you get higher scores, it's incrementally more difficult to keep them up, but we believe we have the best customer service of any anchor in the mall and frankly, we have the only customer service in the off-mall environment. And we think that while that's a big investment, we think that investment in the long term, that builds customer loyalty and allows us to sell merchandise that's more stylish and higher quality as we have someone there to assist the customer with the purchase. We also think robust online access in our stores through our Find More allows our customers to be helped by our sales associates online. All of our sales registers are dot com capable, and We have 100 stores now with Find More specialized fixtures that help with that. So we're very proud of the customer service aspect of it. Our social engagement continues to go up. We think there's a direct correlation between highly engaged associates and highly satisfied customers. So once again, this year, our score went up from 80 to 81 of highly engaged. We think that's a great result given the environment and how hard everybody's working.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Bob Drbul of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Bob Drbul of Barclays Capital.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions, first, could you clarify, on the comp components, I'm having trouble making the math work. I think with some of the numbers that you gave transactions, five now in UPT, 2.3 in AUR down slightly. But the comp was up around 1%. I just don't u
componenttext: Two questions, first, could you clarify, on the comp components, I'm having trouble making the math work. I think with some of the numbers that you gave transactions, five now in UPT, 2.3 in AUR down slightly. But the comp was up around 1%. I just don't understand how those numbers work to get that, Mike.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, as you know, it's difficult because there's a mix issue as well. So if your big-ticket business or fine jewelry business has a change in AUR, obviously, the AUR might be probably six time the AUR of an apparel item on average across that cat
componenttext: First of all, as you know, it's difficult because there's a mix issue as well. So if your big-ticket business or fine jewelry business has a change in AUR, obviously, the AUR might be probably six time the AUR of an apparel item on average across that category. The math works, believe me. It's not hocus pocus. I don't know exactly what you're using, but we gave you the numbers that they use.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: It sounds like Liz is off to a good start. I think when you look back at some of the other new brand launches that you had such as American Living, can you talk about what you've learned from that? And when you look at like MNG by Mango, do you think that
componenttext: It sounds like Liz is off to a good start. I think when you look back at some of the other new brand launches that you had such as American Living, can you talk about what you've learned from that? And when you look at like MNG by Mango, do you think that, that can be as successful? How would you think about that?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let's talk about American Living for a minute. I mean, clearly, 40 categories at once in a recession, at the best price point could not be what you designed at the beginning, but we've moated through that. I'm happy to say our margins at American Living a
componenttext: Let's talk about American Living for a minute. I mean, clearly, 40 categories at once in a recession, at the best price point could not be what you designed at the beginning, but we've moated through that. I'm happy to say our margins at American Living are quite respectable, and we think we have it now with the right marketing and the right imaging, the right assortment, the right sizing, the right price. It's been hard work, but I think we're very proud of American Living. It represents a very important statement on our floor. Liz Claiborne is very different in the sense that it builds on 30 years of an iconic brand. This is the number one or number two most recognized apparel brand by the women of this country so we feel it's much more readily accepted across multiple categories. We're adding it to categories in accessories, in the home that it will be well received from day one. MNG by Mango is, frankly, in a very narrow set of categories. So it's primarily in apparel and accessories and a few handbags. They're very confident about that business and we don't really have to invent anything. We don't have to create the brand from scratch. They have thousands of stores, particularly in Europe, with a very strong alignment to holiday market and the impactful imaging that they have. So we feel that it has a narrower appeal because, obviously, it's a more updated, contemporary customer. But again, it's a very small part of the store as well, less than 2% of the store space.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just my last question is can you talk a little bit more about the Red Zone clearance strategy? And when you look at sort of the back half here, do you think that, that's going to be a bigger component of your comp drivers for the second half of t
componenttext: And then just my last question is can you talk a little bit more about the Red Zone clearance strategy? And when you look at sort of the back half here, do you think that, that's going to be a bigger component of your comp drivers for the second half of the year than it was in the first?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know that it'll necessarily be bigger, but I think we ought to see -- have to finish the year, get through 'til we annualize it. The reality is it's a little complicated to explain in the sense that why it is so important to change it. By adding f
componenttext: I don't know that it'll necessarily be bigger, but I think we ought to see -- have to finish the year, get through 'til we annualize it. The reality is it's a little complicated to explain in the sense that why it is so important to change it. By adding five major events a year, it really forced merchants to hold markdowns so they didn't get doubled up on markdowns. And so things didn't necessarily clear as fast as the customer was willing to clear them. So getting off of that cadence was important even though it's painful. So you're going to hit the five periods where you're up against these big events and you will have sold through some of the clearance that would have been on those events. We are seeing higher AUR by doing it this way. More importantly, it opens the open to buy during that period to put in where in our merchandise. And that's the biggest benefit. So it's a little hard to explain because, frankly, some of the benefit is not showing in the markdown category. It's showing in the sales line. By landing, we're now in June or landing, we're now in January. So as I said, in retrospect, maybe we're too naive about our ability to roll over Route 26 [ph] (1:10:17). And we paid a big price for it in the comps.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Lorraine Hutchinson of Bank of America Corporation.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Lorraine Hutchinson of Bank of America Corporation.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask just won more question on inventory. I guess you had mentioned that x some items, inventory would've been up about 5%, which was in line with your initial sales plan. Now that you're a bit more cautious on the consumer environment in
componenttext: I just wanted to ask just won more question on inventory. I guess you had mentioned that x some items, inventory would've been up about 5%, which was in line with your initial sales plan. Now that you're a bit more cautious on the consumer environment in the back half, what are your plans for that inventory? Can you return it or will we see some more markdowns? I guess, how do expect to get through the somewhat elevated levels of inventory?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: We expect to sell it, which is the first reaction. We'll know more after the month of August, obviously, because landing all the new Liz and all the new growth initiatives merchandise, much of it directed at the back-to-school customers. So obviously, wha
componenttext: We expect to sell it, which is the first reaction. We'll know more after the month of August, obviously, because landing all the new Liz and all the new growth initiatives merchandise, much of it directed at the back-to-school customers. So obviously, what you don't sell, you obviously have to take price changes to get rid of it. But given the fact that we're reacting for the whole season not just for one month, we'll project out the units we want to own by the various out date, and make sure that we don't end the season in fall, in the very position that we don't want to be. So we've been very fortunate to have clean inventories coming into spring. So we don't have a lot of carryovers. As a matter of fact we probably don't have enough clearance to be up against some of the clearance selling we had a year ago. So I'd much rather have current inventory ready for back-to-school than have a lot of summer left over. The fact that it's a  billion degrees in some part of the country doesn't serve us well in that area, but in the long run you want to be basically ready for the future season.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Michael Exstein from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Michael Exstein from Credit Suisse.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: One thing that you didn't mention about is for the change in promotions that you are doing, you've been running $10, $15 coupons most weekend, can you talk about that change in strategy? And also, can you give us the order of magnitude of the unfortunate
componenttext: One thing that you didn't mention about is for the change in promotions that you are doing, you've been running $10, $15 coupons most weekend, can you talk about that change in strategy? And also, can you give us the order of magnitude of the unfortunate reversal of the accrual for bonuses?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Frankly, our sales promotion is fairly comparable to a year ago. We certainly haven't added events related to discounts. You're going to see us make some promotional changes in the back that we think will make it clear to the customer the value their gett
componenttext: Frankly, our sales promotion is fairly comparable to a year ago. We certainly haven't added events related to discounts. You're going to see us make some promotional changes in the back that we think will make it clear to the customer the value their getting at JCPenney. We think we've been at disadvantage because we haven't messaged it particularly effectively. But we don't -- unlike some of our competitors, we're not really layering in additional promotion. We think we're up against that forever if you put it back in. We put 50 days out last year. We're not going to return there. As to the incentive comp, I don't think it's any secret at the end of the first quarter, we were well ahead of plan. So we accrued our incentive compensation above the plan levels for our executives and our managers. And obviously, we had to bring it back to what the trend is now because we not only accrued for above half of year-to-date, but we also accrued for the forecast. So obviously, it reflects what we think the reality is going to be for the second half of the year. The quantum of it, frankly, I don't have it in front of me, but it was --

componenttextpreview: Not meaningful.
componenttext: Not meaningful.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Wayne Hood of BMO capital.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Wayne Hood of BMO capital.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on Mike's question there. Are you saying that you won't bring back the number of days that you have discounts, which we understand, but would we expect to see some layering of promotions to kind of get the consumer to respond a little bit
componenttext: Just a follow-up on Mike's question there. Are you saying that you won't bring back the number of days that you have discounts, which we understand, but would we expect to see some layering of promotions to kind of get the consumer to respond a little bit maybe more two for one? Can you describe a little bit more in the fourth quarter if the fall season what you -- what the plan is?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say that we're not going to layer in additional discounts. We're not going to add any additional promotional days. So we have a promotional plan for the fall season. We think it's effective. Obviously, every week we look to make sure that we are c
componenttext: I would say that we're not going to layer in additional discounts. We're not going to add any additional promotional days. So we have a promotional plan for the fall season. We think it's effective. Obviously, every week we look to make sure that we are comfortable with our ongoing plans. But we don't run promotions on an ad hoc basis. These things are planned out after requiring every market in every media, digital or non-digital and media and print. We're not going to layer in additional promotions. We think the promotion we run now is effective. We want to make it a little clear to the customer so we make messages somewhat differently, but it doesn't mean it's an additional discount.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Bob, can you unbundle, I guess, the second quarter gross margin rate increase? How much of an increase did the store see? And when you strip out catalog and the other things that are impacting that? And when you guys talk about a modest decline in gro
componenttext: And Bob, can you unbundle, I guess, the second quarter gross margin rate increase? How much of an increase did the store see? And when you strip out catalog and the other things that are impacting that? And when you guys talk about a modest decline in gross margin in the third quarter, can you put some parameters around what you define as modest? Because in the last quarter, you expected a modest increase in Europe almost 90 basis points. Is modest more like 50 for you? And then into the fourth quarter, can we expect another modest decline against the difficult compare?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Taking the, Wayne, your question regarding the second quarter first here. As Mike indicated earlier with his remarks on the impact on the Big Books and the profitability that they had generated, the second quarter impact there on the margins from a direct
componenttext: Taking the, Wayne, your question regarding the second quarter first here. As Mike indicated earlier with his remarks on the impact on the Big Books and the profitability that they had generated, the second quarter impact there on the margins from a direct to stores, obviously, there was a negative impact or hit, if you will, from the big books on margin and a further improvement, of course, therefore, on the stores.  So with regard to the third quarter, I think modest decline was, as Mike said, really in our plan as we prepared for the year and in terms of modification. But we don't normally give out prospective margin numbers. I think we're historic highest. Last year's margin for the year was the highest in the company's history. I think the second quarter margin is the highest, at least in a decade. So I think we certainly don't feel like we have margin pressure by any surprises coming. I think it's a question of flow through and sell through. We keep churning merchandise as we have been, we're getting the favorable margin that we plan for.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think also, Wayne, if you run through with your respective models between the 2%, the 3% comps, I think you'd be able, with the guidance from the SG&A and the other variables, really back into the high and low range on the $0.16 to $0.20 per sh
componenttext: Yes, and I think also, Wayne, if you run through with your respective models between the 2%, the 3% comps, I think you'd be able, with the guidance from the SG&A and the other variables, really back into the high and low range on the $0.16 to $0.20 per share and you will have then what our perspective of modest is for the third quarter.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Sean Naughton of Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Sean Naughton of Piper Jaffray.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just another follow-up on the gross margin. Can you tell us, are you expecting to have favorable sourcing costs in the back half and the gross margin pressure is really more from some additional promotions that you may be having in order to drive some tra
componenttext: Just another follow-up on the gross margin. Can you tell us, are you expecting to have favorable sourcing costs in the back half and the gross margin pressure is really more from some additional promotions that you may be having in order to drive some traffic into your stores?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: We certainly know the back half costing because those goods are already bought, and I would say that's slightly favorable as a factor. The real issue on gross profit in the back half is, obviously, the cadence of sell-through. If the merchandise continues
componenttext: We certainly know the back half costing because those goods are already bought, and I would say that's slightly favorable as a factor. The real issue on gross profit in the back half is, obviously, the cadence of sell-through. If the merchandise continues to flow through and sold early in the cycle, obviously margins are better. If it tends to get higher in sell through, obviously, sales in the clearance pricing goes up and sales in the promotional and regular pricing goes down. So our experience so far this year has been good. So we made the right decisions on what to buy and we made the right decisions on how to promote it. We would expect to continue to have favorable GP result.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of just your regional performance and the comp trend, is there anything in particular that you're seeing in different states now that may have had -- real estate markets that are not recover as quickly as you would've liked? And then also mor
componenttext: And in terms of just your regional performance and the comp trend, is there anything in particular that you're seeing in different states now that may have had -- real estate markets that are not recover as quickly as you would've liked? And then also more specifically, potentially on California, obviously, we don't have the Mervyn closures that we did last year, which was a pretty direct comparison. Can you make any comment on the regional trends around the country that you're seeing?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, you pointed out that California's pretty tough. I would say, overall, that we've experienced that as well. We're up against strong comparables and also the economy there has been one of the most impacted by the housing situation. The Southe
componenttext: Well, clearly, you pointed out that California's pretty tough. I would say, overall, that we've experienced that as well. We're up against strong comparables and also the economy there has been one of the most impacted by the housing situation. The Southeast was the strongest for us in the spring, and probably twice the trend of the average. So I would say the Northeast was weaker for us and the spring as well, although it's gotten stronger as the season went on. So our business right now in the Northeast is quite good. So it varies by week. As I said, right now, Texas looks terrific because back-to-school is upon us. We're having very strong increases in Dallas, Houston, San Antonio, Austin, Fort Worth.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the marketing, obviously, you've got some good brands in the store with Mango and Liz Claiborne coming online with some strong national brands. What strategies are you really using, from a marketing perspective, to really communicate with that younger
componenttext: On the marketing, obviously, you've got some good brands in the store with Mango and Liz Claiborne coming online with some strong national brands. What strategies are you really using, from a marketing perspective, to really communicate with that younger consumer and let them know that this product is in the store and where to find that today?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we've improved our messaging pretty dramatically in terms of Little Red Book in Women's and Matters of Styl in Men's, which are now much more updated in their appearance. I think if you would take a catalog or a piece of direct mail from three or
componenttext: I think we've improved our messaging pretty dramatically in terms of Little Red Book in Women's and Matters of Styl in Men's, which are now much more updated in their appearance. I think if you would take a catalog or a piece of direct mail from three or four years ago and put alongside what we're producing today, it's a dramatic difference. It's not your mother's department store. I think our strategy is, obviously, get imaging that reflects the style and character and quality of the merchandise, and the customers responded very well to it. We know we're under indexed in that younger customer segment in the 24- to 35-year-old customer. We think that's a big opportunity for us because, frankly, the ones that are coming in the store, finding merchandise, where they do, is significantly lower prices than other department stores. So as much as other department stores talk about trading into our area, net price is customers still significantly higher. So our job is, obviously, to communicate as effectively as possible to a broad range of customers that give us a chance for them to come and discover Mango. It's called Spring [Call It Spring] by ALDO Group or Claiborne, where it's now exclusively at Penney's. We know that in our research before acquiring the brand that customers who are shopping for Liz Claiborne in other department stores said they would follow the brand, not the store. It was obviously a big incentive for us to go after Claiborne on an exclusive basis.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our last question is coming from Erika Maschmeyer of Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our last question is coming from Erika Maschmeyer of Robert W. Baird.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to follow up on the promotions that you talked about. And could you just lay out a little bit more of your expectations for the competitive promotional environment? It sounds like you expect a ramp up in promotions for your competition.
componenttext: I want to follow up on the promotions that you talked about. And could you just lay out a little bit more of your expectations for the competitive promotional environment? It sounds like you expect a ramp up in promotions for your competition.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's hard to believe that any of us could actually add more promotion, if you look at the landscape. But as I said, I think ours has been effective. But where we look at ways to improve it, it's probably in the mix of how we talk about our business, as we
componenttext: It's hard to believe that any of us could actually add more promotion, if you look at the landscape. But as I said, I think ours has been effective. But where we look at ways to improve it, it's probably in the mix of how we talk about our business, as well as the clarity of offers. So we had a big effort a year ago on pricing clarity and communication. That has proven to be very successful. I would argue that one of the reasons our Men's business is so strong is we reorganized the layout, reorganized the messaging and the clarity and the customers responded very well, to the extent that those principles are now being applied to across all our businesses. Looking at some of the improvements in Home, I would argue that's part of the success there as well. So just adding money to the promotion bucket doesn't necessarily change the result. The effectiveness is what matters. We already are one of the largest of the 20 advertisers in the United States, so it's not as if we're not spending in the category. But we have a very diverse business. We've got Window Covering and Furniture and Beauty Salon and so forth. So we've got a lot of other different businesses under one roof. And the mixing of the messaging plus digital, print and store to give the customer the appropriate view of what the offer is at JCPenney and why they should consider it that we're on a journey to a store that they're going to find very appealing.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you also talk about how the performance at your Home business has differed between online and in the stores and the reasons behind that?
componenttext: Could you also talk about how the performance at your Home business has differed between online and in the stores and the reasons behind that?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the online offer is quite broad. And for example, in infant and baby furniture, we don't really carry that in the store, but we have a very broad assortment online. And there are other examples of that. So we might have, say, 25 beds on the floor, i
componenttext: Well, the online offer is quite broad. And for example, in infant and baby furniture, we don't really carry that in the store, but we have a very broad assortment online. And there are other examples of that. So we might have, say, 25 beds on the floor, in a regular store. We might have over 100 beds, in terms of top of bed fashion online or in catalog. So one of the things we're looking at very carefully is how to better align the store assortments for online because we know that, that is the way the customers are using the shop. In some cases, we're over assorted online. We have too much merchandise and then in the distribution centers, waiting for the customers. In other cases, we don't have enough. So putting the merchant organizations together, they're working day by day trying to make sure what the right balance is between online and in-store presence. The good news is we have total visibility of inventory in every store and online, and the customer as well as the associate totally have access to the online assortment at the store, from home or anywhere else. So we think that's a big advantage. We've been at it for five years. We've had online access for five years in our store. 35,000 to 40,000 places other people are just now learning about.
