componenttext: Greetings, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the JCPenney Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ms. Kristin Hays, Vice President of Investor Relations. Thank you, Ms. Hays, you may begin.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Claudia, and thank you all for joining us on the call this morning to review JCPenney's third quarter earnings.Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of
componenttext:
Thank you, Claudia, and thank you all for joining us on the call this morning to review JCPenney's third quarter earnings.
Before we begin, let me remind everyone that the discussion this morning includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, which reflects the company's current view of future events and financial performance. The words expect, plan, anticipate, believe and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements.
Any such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, and the company's of future results of operation could differ materially from historical results or current expectations. For more details on these risks, please refer to the company's Form 10-K and other SEC filings.
Also, please note that no portion of this call may be rebroadcast in any form without prior written consent of JCPenney. Replays of today's webcast will be available for 90 days. For those listening after November 12, 2010, please note that this recording will not be updated, and it is possible that the information discussed will no longer be current.
On this morning's call, we will have two speakers: First, Mike Ullman, JCPenney's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Bob Cavanaugh, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Now I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thanks for joining us today. This morning, we announced third quarter results of $0.19 per share. Now this reflects the combination of the actions we're taking to drive our top line with our continued focus on managing our costs and expe
componenttext:
Good morning, and thanks for joining us today. This morning, we announced third quarter results of $0.19 per share. Now this reflects the combination of the actions we're taking to drive our top line with our continued focus on managing our costs and expenses in order to drive profitability. In fact, expenses came in even lower than we planned.
Earlier this year, we told you that our performance for the year would be second half loaded and that's exactly the way it's played out in spite of unseasonal weather in many areas of the country during the period. Our third quarter results reflect our growth initiatives, are waiting to take hold, and we feel good about the way we're positioned for the all-important Christmas season in the fourth quarter. I should note that November is off to a great start, since the weather has turned more seasonable in many parts of the country. With that, let me review our sales for the third quarter. I'll start with an update on the work being done by our co-chief merchants Liz Sweeney and Steve Lawrence, and their teams to continue to raise the style offering of our merchandise assortments. Specifically, the combination of the new looks we've introduced with new marketing approaches is serving us well. Here are a few highlights: first we began introducing Liz Claiborne, one of the nation's most recognized brands in August. It's in all 1,107 of our stores with the vast majority of our stores carrying all 26 categories of Liz Claiborne and Claiborne merchandise. The brand end is beating our plan across all businesses.
Second, our Men's business has been a top performer across the company year-to-date. This is due to the team's strategic decision to shift more of our merchandise mix into good and better price points, along with the improved level of style we now carry and the marketing which is targeted directly to male consumers.
Overall, we're very satisfied with this business we had a strong Father's Day and we're experiencing a strong trend in Men's since Father's Day. Third, the addition of MNG by Mango. This unique fast fashion brand is offered exclusively at JCPenney. It's drawn great attention to our contemporary assortments. MNG is now in 77 stores and performing well, with particular strength in our metropolitan stores. This brand will be in 600 stores at this time next year. Fourth, Call it Spring by ALDO launched in three stores this quarter will also be in 600 stores this time next year.
Prior this launch, we have already made considerable changes in our overall Modern Shoe and Handbag businesses, which has delivered strong results for us thus far. So with the addition of Call it Spring we feel very good about the future of our Modern Shoe and Handbag business. Fifth, in fine jewelry, our added assortments and introduction of new fashionable finds and re-brands at shopper price points is clearly resonated with our customers. Throughout the third quarter, find joy is one of our top performing divisions. Sixth, support inside JCPenney, once again this concert was a star performer. As of today, we're in 231 locations performing very well. On average, the foreign side JCPenney locations are 3x more productive than the rest of the store. We plan to open additional 75 stores inside JCPenney in 2011 and will have a total of 600 by the year 2014. Also I'd like to note that the growth initiatives we announced at the analyst meeting early in the year, all 14 growth initiatives are up year-to-date and ahead of our plan. To remind you, some of these were in the tops category across Juniors, Men's, Boys and Women's, our center core businesses, Fashion Jewelry, The National Brand Draw business, Ore and Metals and Fine Jewelry, Modern Shoes, Modern Handbags as well as our Kids business. So we feel good about identifying the growth opportunities, we knew the consumer wasn't going to help us much this year, we had to create our own growth and are quite pleased that we delivered on that objective.
Our marketing initiatives were also playing a critical role in this. JCPenney is one of the top 20 marketers in the country and we spend our dollars strategically in search of the reached the broadest group of costumers while ensuring we target our messages to read the right customers with the right messages in a way that relates to their lifestyle.
Overall, the changes we've made are attracting new customers to JCPenney as well as reaching an increasing number of younger customers who are attracted to our stepped-up style and compelling price points. 
We are also pursuing new marketing initiatives such as the partnership with People Style Watch. This alignment lends great credibility to our style authority and encourages customers to discover the new higher level of  fashion in merchandise assortments. Throughout the year, People Style Watch editors work with our trend and merchandising  teams to select must-haves from our fashion assortments focusing on women's and juniors apparel, accessories and footwear.
Since launching, the People Style Watch must-haves in store and at jcp.com, the results are very encouraging. Must haves items that are online essentially sell out. In our stores we've experienced some 25% sales lift on average, over the rest of selling for those things that have been identified as must-haves by those editors.
We're also in the process of integrating the rest of our print media from traditional catalogs to targeted print pieces. Future print media will be fully aligned to store at jcp.com assortments, and supported by enterprise-wide merchandising marketing and planning allocation. Our fine war print media will provide store selling associates additional support to help customers find the extended sizes and/or additional JCP merchandise offerings from one of our 40,000 .com-enabled terminals in our stores that they can also shop from home or from mobile devices using to find more media.
As we transition out of the Catalog business, we are working to rationalize certain assets related to our catalog operations, which we expect to result in expense savings over the long term.
Moving back now to the results for the quarter. We delivered 1.9% growth in comparable store sales. Our third consecutive quarter comparable store gains.  We're delivering on the promise for sequential sales growth during the year. Our quarterly comp includes a 2.3% gain in August and 5.1% comparable gain in September, making us once again a leader in the key back-to-school period. Customers responded well to the new brands, such as Uproar and Supergirl by Nastia as well as some of the long-term leaders including Arizona and national brands such as Zoo York and Vans. This performance early in the quarter was partially offset by our sales results in October. The facts there were that October was one of the warmest in 30 years and one of the driest in 20 years across the country and this impacted sales across our industry.
The bright spot for us is the non-seasoned merchandise category such as housewares, luggage, fashion jewelry continued to perform well and support to as a strong performer once again in October.
Traffic in our stores, both on and off mall, was up year-over-year for each month. Additionally the number of transactions and units per transaction were also up low to mid single digits over the year. And we'll note that the traffic in our off-mall locations was about 600 basis points higher than the traffic in our regional mall locations.
AUR was down for the quarter, which was our plan. Early this year we began a strategic effort to shift a greater portion of our assortments to good-better pricing versus better-best, as customers continue to be very price conscious. Through our industry sourcing organization which allows us to mitigate the costing pressures, and still maintain strong profitability, we were able to offer our customers sharp price points as well as stay true to our mission of being a commercial department store that America's families can rely on for affordable fashion. Additionally, we made it easier for our customers to recognize the value of our offer to our focus on our merchandising price clarity.
jcp.com experienced sales gains throughout the period of 3% for the quarter, which reflects solid performance across all categories as well as a continued positive impact given by our guided navigation technology with the success of our social media strategy to drive traffic to our site and the appeal of our free shipping offers. The strongest performing categories were men's as well as shoes and women's accessories and we also delivered positive sales on home categories online as growth initiatives in this business are striking to take hold on jcp.com, as well as in our stores.
Total inventory was up about 5% over last year. This includes an increase approximately 5% of customer based inventory over last year which is in line with both the company's initial sales plan for the fourth quarter and our targeted year-end inventory's reported growth initiatives entering next year. We believe we're in an appropriate and good inventory position entering the holiday season and we expect this to serve us well as we work to ensure that our price points are competitive in this highly promotional environment. Additionally, to remind you, we lost sales during the holiday season last year, because we thought our inventories were too low.
This year, JCPenney will be appropriately stocked throughout the period. With that, let me now turn it over, the call over to Bob for more detail on our financials.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. I will be speaking with you this morning about our financial results and outlook. Mike will then close with additional color around our plans for the fourth quarter and our growth initiatives before we open the ca
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. I will be speaking with you this morning about our financial results and outlook. Mike will then close with additional color around our plans for the fourth quarter and our growth initiatives before we open the call to questions. This morning, we reported third quarter earnings of $0.19 per share. This result reflects the team's focus on driving top line sales through our growth initiatives, while also continuing to manage our cost and expenses in order to drive profitability and deliver shareholder value. For the third quarter in a row, the company reported positive comparable store sales gains against last year as comparable store sales for the quarter increased 1.9%, essentially in line with our sales guidance for the quarter. As Mike mentioned, sales in August and September were strong, but this strength was offset by the company's performance in October as weather for the month was unseasonably warm, negatively impacting the sell-through cold-weather merchandise.
Gross margin decreased $61 million for the third quarter to 39% of sales, primarily due to the discontinuation of our Big Book catalogs, promotional activities during the quarter and in part, to the shift in our merchandise mix to more items at good and better price points.
Although we guided for SG&A dollars to increase 2%, we are pleased that our teams were able to reduce SG&A dollars by 3.8% when compared to last year. For example, the company launched Liz Claiborne during the quarter, which was supported by a successful and expensive marketing campaign, yet marketing expenses were actually down year-over-year as we reallocated print spend to local and national advertising and online media. The company also benefited from the efficiencies we continue to generate through our tools and processes like jTime and door to floor, which helped to manage store staffing to customer traffic. In addition, the company also recorded a reduction in its incentive compensation accrual, which positively impacted SG&A for the quarter.
Total operating expenses were down significantly to last year, declining 4.9% or $78 million. Operating income for the quarter was up 15.9% to $124 million compared with $107 million last year. As noted in the release, if we exclude the impact of the non-cash qualified pension plan expense from both this year's and last year's third quarter, adjusted operating income was flat both in dollars and as a percent of sales. Interest expense for the quarter was $57 million compared to $64 million in the prior year, reflecting both lower debt and interest rate levels.
The effective tax rate for the quarter was 34.3%. This is lower than expected due to a positive adjustment resulting from the true up to actuals after the filing of the company's tax return. And we had approximately $238 million average diluted shares for the quarter. For the bottom line, net income improved 63% to $44 million or $0.19 per share for the quarter. Adjusting net income for the impact of the qualifying pension plan, net income increased 11% to $80 million or $0.34 a share, up 13%.
Moving onto our financial condition. We remain in a strong financial position with continued flexibility to support the key components of our growth initiatives and the Long Range Plan. As of October 30, the company had cash and cash equivalents of approximately $1.7 billion. Year-to-date, our free cash flow remains on plan to end the year at approximately $200 million.
Also capital expenditures for the nine months reported were approximately $380 million as we continue to reinvest in our existing stores and our growth initiatives. We continue to expect full year capital expenditures to be approximately $500 million. As announced earlier this week and as Mike will discuss, we are also investing in two high potential retail opportunities designed to grow our sales by expanding our customer reach into new ventures online, Gifting Grace and CLAD. Turning now to the company's outlook for the remainder of the year.
We expect comparable store sales to be up 3% or 4% in the fourth quarter. Due to the company's discontinuation of its Big Book catalogs, total sales are expected to increase approximately 150 basis points less than comparable store sales.
For the quarter, we expect gross margins as a percent of sales to modestly decline. And as a reminder, the company is up against historic peak margins achieved in last year's fourth quarter. SG&A dollars are expected to increase approximately 1% to 2% in the quarter. Depreciation and amortization should be approximately $141 million. Net interest expense should be about $58 million and we expect a tax rate of approximately 37%.
We currently anticipate about 238 million average diluted shares including about 2 million common stock equivalents. Earnings for the fourth quarter are expected to be in the range of $0.90 to $1 per share and for the full year, the company still expects comparable store sales to increase low single digits and for earnings to be in the range of $1.40 to $1.50 per share. In summary, as we move into the fourth quarter, we are confident that our continued focus on disciplined execution of our business and our long-range plan strategies will foster financial flexibility and further strengthen our business for long-term success.
Now, I'll turn the call over to Mike Ullman for more details on the company's performance and outlook.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob. Now that Bob has told you about our expectations for the fourth quarter. Let me shed some light on what's driving them. We have exciting plans in place for the Christmas holiday. At the end of October, we launched a dedicated gift hub onli
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob. Now that Bob has told you about our expectations for the fourth quarter. Let me shed some light on what's driving them. We have exciting plans in place for the Christmas holiday. At the end of October, we launched a dedicated gift hub online. Gives our customers an easy way to view all we have up in the season categorized by age, price and other ways to make it easy and convenient to buy gifts from JCPenney.
Second, our stores are now fully set for the Christmas holiday. Additionally this season, 200 JCPenney stores that don't currently have a support inside JCPenney beauty boutique. We're featuring a pop-up shop carrying a selection of sought after beauty and fragrance products and gift sets.
Third, we've increased our marketing spend in the fourth quarter to ensure there's a very loud steady drumbeat tauting JCPenney as the Christmas gift headquarters. Our integrated marketing campaign which includes a very robust promotional counter will highlight our competitive merchandise offering. And additionally, we just launched a new mobile commerce site this week, so customers can shop directly from their smartphones. 
On November 1, we began a free shipment return to store program as well for all orders made online or through mobile applications. We think this is a unique offering among our peer group. Finally, we are offering special incentives for our JCP Rewards customers during the Christmas holiday season. Our rewards program now has over 24 million members. 
Before we open the call to your questions, I want to quickly touch on some of the longer-term initiatives we're pursuing for 2011 and beyond. We announced a couple of weeks ago that we plan to expand our presence in major markets, which are currently underserved by JCPenney and offer great potential for us to our demographic profiles. This should begin next year with the opening of three new stores, one in San Francisco Bay area, one in suburban Maryland just outside Washington DC, and in Central Dallas and we expect to announce further details on our new start growth plans shortly. At the same time, we're committed to elevating in store JCPenney experience through our comprehensive renovation program. This year in 2010, we made significant in-store enhancements in more than 750 stores, including 76 major renovations and by 2014, we plan to complete major remodels in more than 375 additional source.
Taken together, these new openings and renovation program will help enable JCPenney to deliver on our goal of being an industry growth leader by maximizing sales productivity in our existing locations and expanding our customer base in key markets.
Additionally, we announced yesterday the creation of a new business, the Growth Brands Division, which will pursue high potential opportunities in the retail sector. These initiatives will be separate from our core JCPenney brand and will capitalize in our retail expertise in strategically pursuing untapped opportunities to serve key customer segments and drive sales growth.
Our opportunities initiatives will include both digital and retail store opportunities reflects our long range plan objective of growth leadership in the industry . The first two businesses under this new division, CLAD and Gifting Grace will launch in summer of 2011 and both are strategic collaborations with the First Magazine group.
The First Magazine group will lend its vast brand expertise in consumer reach. We will leverage our industry-leading retail infrastructure. Both initiatives will be Online Retail businesses and are unlikely to be like anything that exists in the market today. CLAD will be a complete online modern menswear resource aimed at fashionable men offering a full assortment of well curated [ph] designer brands in a savvy digital environment.
This business will be run Will Swillie, who joins us after having just built the Men's business at Rue La La. Gifting Grace will be a compressive online gifting resource offering extensive assortment of unique and memorable gift items compelling content and convenient tools for the year-around gift giver. This will be led by Mary Drolet, the retail patron and founder of Club Libby Lu. Will and Mary will both report to Anne Sutherland Fuchs, a highly experienced branding and digital executive who recently joined us.
Along with our new growth brands division, we're continuing our transformational journey of our core JCPenney brand into a destination for discovering great style and compelling prices.
We believe we enjoy a very solid position in regional malls as the price leader among the anchor tenants and at the same time in off mall locations, we offer the only true department store experience at affordable and compelling prices. Lastly, I'd like to congratulate all of our 150,000 associates for just completing our fourth year of our GREAT customer service program. Great stands for greet, respect, engage, assist and thank. We've enjoyed for the last two years being number one in customer service among stores in the U.S. and it's a great credit to our sales associates for their diligence in this area.
Their continued dedication to serving our customers has really differentiated us from the competition, fares us well to deliver to our customers during the Christmas holiday season. So now operator, please open the line for questions.

componenttext: It's a similar situation we have our consumer facing inventories up 5%, which is pretty much in line with our expectations of satisfying our plans for the fourth quarter as well as being properly positioned going into 2011. So the rest is on the water or enroute. We feel very comfortable with inventory levels to a certain extent the unseasonal weather has a bit higher at the end of the October period but the first 10 and 11 days of November has resolved that issue. We're quite comfortable with inventory levels.

componenttext: And Mike, have you surprised by the impact of the elimination of Big Books?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think what we've been surprised by is a difficult it's been to navigate through getting out of it without having negative impact on the .com business. If you look at our gross margin decline in the third quarter, 2/3 of it was related to catalog or
componenttext: Well I think what we've been surprised by is a difficult it's been to navigate through getting out of it without having negative impact on the .com business. If you look at our gross margin decline in the third quarter, 2/3 of it was related to catalog or direct issues. Only a third of it was marked down based on seasonal merchandise. So I would say that was more impact than we had anticipated. But we'll be through this, it's not recurring in '11 and we want to get it behind us in 2010.

componenttext: Well we've noted that we're not starting to see gains on Home online, as well in the stores particularly in housewares, luggage, some of the softer categories. The Window Covering and Furniture business tends to be the softness business in terms of returning to a growth profile. I think this reflects kind of where the customers is at the moment. Credit constriction in the overall economy. But I think the changes that John and his team have made are right on and are starting to resonate with customers.

componenttextpreview: Units per transaction are up and the number of units sold is up and we've said beginning the quarter we have been modestly declining AUR and it's also the customer opting for opening price point assortments that are sharp in price. We sent our customer sc
componenttext: Units per transaction are up and the number of units sold is up and we've said beginning the quarter we have been modestly declining AUR and it's also the customer opting for opening price point assortments that are sharp in price. We sent our customer score card back and we're number one in price clarity. So we think we've accomplished our objective in improving price communication and clarity in the store and we think that's key to our success in winning the game on having affordable compelling pricing for the customer.

componenttext: We are not giving guidance by month. I don't think that it's helpful at this point. And my comment as it stands, I mean we feel great about the business so far this month. Obviously all apparel retailers have experienced a return of solid growth now that the weather is cooler in the upper half of the U.S. Our strength in the October period was in the Southern two regions, as well as in the categories that were less temperature specific. That gives us some encouragement the way we plan the fourth quarter is likely to play out.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010

componenttext: And then just to follow-up on the gross profit guidance for the fourth quarter. I believe for 3Q, you set them modestly and you wound up being down on 160 basis points. Was that in line with what you thought? And I guess therefore should we think that GPM is down another 160 bps in the fourth quarter? Obviously the comparison gets a little bit harder?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think I just answered that question, that 2/3 of the drop in the third quarter was catalog. So I  would consider the 1/3 of it is modestly down. And I would still consider that the fourth quarter is once again to be modestly down â weâll have some e
componenttext: I think I just answered that question, that 2/3 of the drop in the third quarter was catalog. So I  would consider the 1/3 of it is modestly down. And I would still consider that the fourth quarter is once again to be modestly down â weâll have some effect of the Catalog business till we get completely out of it. But keep in mind we're up against historic margins a year ago, the highest in the company's history in the fourth quarter to the extent that we can sell through goods early in the cycle and our clearance strategy kicks in as it has in the first three quarters the we have our reason to be optimistic about our margins. Theyâre industry leading model for our peer groups so we feel confident that, that continues to be one of our strengths.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then my last question is just on the SG&A guidance. Obviously a big swing factor here in the third quarter relative to your initial view. When you look at the fourth quarter, do you feel you have the same ability to flex down if, let's say, hypothetic
componenttext: And then my last question is just on the SG&A guidance. Obviously a big swing factor here in the third quarter relative to your initial view. When you look at the fourth quarter, do you feel you have the same ability to flex down if, let's say, hypothetically sales do come in below 3% to 4% range?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well we do have a jTime planning tool that allows us to modify the selling expense which is our biggest single expense category particularly during the fourth quarter. We think we do that extremely well and that benefits us as we navigate through it week
componenttext: Well we do have a jTime planning tool that allows us to modify the selling expense which is our biggest single expense category particularly during the fourth quarter. We think we do that extremely well and that benefits us as we navigate through it week by week. In terms of the expense issue in the third quarter, we did have some savings in marketing as we more or less reserve marketing spend for the fourth quarter so we won't see that benefit in terms of expense reduction, we actually want to invest it in the fourth quarter. As you well know, the biggest opportunity we have is leveraging expenses by continuing to deliver on our growth initiatives and that we feel we're well positioned to do that. With the inventories position, the way we're promoting the goods and the customersâ response through back-to-school, Father's Day and this is another appointment shopping paired with a regional mall tends to have an advantage. So we think we're as well positioned as we can be going to the fourth quarter.

componenttext: Would you be willing to quantify the bonus accrual, how much that helped out?

componenttext: Chuck, we're not going to quantify that at this point in time. It was, as Mike indicated, it was a meaningful component as I said in my remarks. But we also indicated as Mike just mentioned the savings and re-purposed advertising and we also have some good operational benefits in many areas of the store in addition to the jTime benefits.

componenttext: It is fair to say that if I wouldn't have spent savings since we had seen profit, we'd have seasonal weather to the extent that it returns to some more seasonal pattern, the incentive comp number probably gets closer to plan.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Adrianne Shapira with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Adrianne Shapira with Goldman Sachs.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, just hoping to follow-up on the gross margin topic it sounds as if about 100 basis points of the gross margin deterioration related to the Big Book discontinuation. Just wondering it sounds as if we should assume that, just happening to understand w
componenttext: Mike, just hoping to follow-up on the gross margin topic it sounds as if about 100 basis points of the gross margin deterioration related to the Big Book discontinuation. Just wondering it sounds as if we should assume that, just happening to understand why shouldn't we assume that continued into the fourth quarter? Sounds as if it's a similar impact to the top line of 150 basis points. So with that lingering into the fourth quarter, why wouldn't gross margins be impacted similarly?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well there's some technical issues that make it different. For example, we had two of the Big Books overlapped beginning in the third quarter. So it was probably more severe than we'd do in the fourth quarter. As we start to wind down it's less of an issu
componenttext: Well there's some technical issues that make it different. For example, we had two of the Big Books overlapped beginning in the third quarter. So it was probably more severe than we'd do in the fourth quarter. As we start to wind down it's less of an issue. As I've said, we want to be out of this business by the end of the quarter, so our anticipation at this point is it will not be a big factor. The issue of how jcp.com performs over holiday obviously will impact the overall margin, the direct category. We think we can transition all these business that we're walking away from in terms of the traditional catalog and the different print media vehicles like, fine war print media. This actually would be accretive to our margin as far as de-leveraging the inventory as well as the print media form. We're not getting out of the Print business, but we're getting out of the traditional Catalog business, which was tied to call centers and fulfillment processes and specific actions by customers to go online to enter in order that they first saw in the catalog. So re-purposing all of that, we get the inventory aligned with more of a store inventory, so we actually have the youngest customer being the predominant customer on the Internet as opposed to the oldest we think over time is a very important shift.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just following up the other component of the margin hit related to that shift to look good and better. Can you give us a sense, where do you think you stand now in terms of your price position as we head into the fourth quarter? How intense the promotiona
componenttext: Just following up the other component of the margin hit related to that shift to look good and better. Can you give us a sense, where do you think you stand now in terms of your price position as we head into the fourth quarter? How intense the promotional cadence? How much more you to invest in price given today's consumer?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we'll see the pattern continue. This is not some kind of unplanned approach to running the business. We don't have any what I'd call unplanned promotions for the holiday season. I think Mens has been the leader within our merchandise categories on
componenttext: I think we'll see the pattern continue. This is not some kind of unplanned approach to running the business. We don't have any what I'd call unplanned promotions for the holiday season. I think Mens has been the leader within our merchandise categories on the price clarity, communication and the ship to the good price points. And that's what we see happening in the fourth quarter as well. The bigger piece of the margin hit in the third quarter was really weather-related markdowns, wasn't so much the change in mix we had planned to a certain extent.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just following on that, obviously a big topic today sort of a power inflation, help us think about how you're thinking about in the first half, in the second half? Just walk us through some of the sourcing initiatives to help mitigate some of tho
componenttext: And then just following on that, obviously a big topic today sort of a power inflation, help us think about how you're thinking about in the first half, in the second half? Just walk us through some of the sourcing initiatives to help mitigate some of those cost pressures and how you're thinking about passing that through to the consumer?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: We obviously bought the first half of the year, we feel that by working with our major suppliers that we've navigated with that major impact on pricing in the first half. I think many of our competitors work with smaller suppliers may have had more diffic
componenttext: We obviously bought the first half of the year, we feel that by working with our major suppliers that we've navigated with that major impact on pricing in the first half. I think many of our competitors work with smaller suppliers may have had more difficulty dealing with that but we got ahead of it. Cotton prices have been the biggest driver of concern throughout '11 and particularly in second half. In some cases manufacturers aren't even taking orders at this point because they don't feel like they can anticipate what their costing is going to be. We're in better shape than that. We are able to place orders. Once again, we will work hard to try to change the offering in such a way to shield the price increase as much as possible from the consumer, but the fact is if cotton goes up 50% or 70% or whatever it lands, there will be an impact on pricing that everybody in our industry is going to feel. And our objective is to have a competitive advantage particularly on key price points that the customer would expect us to maintain. This can be done obviously through a change in mix, in terms of how we promote the business, but importantly how we manage the costing in Asia. Having the ability to move between countries, the ability to move within a very established supplier base that works with us hand in hand, I think is an advantage. And I don't think anybody is going to be insulated from the pressures that are there.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: So just to be clear, It sounds like the first half no impact, but the second half, could you shed some light and quantify?
componenttext: So just to be clear, It sounds like the first half no impact, but the second half, could you shed some light and quantify?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think I did, but I'll say it again. Some manufacturers aren't even taking orders. That would imply that it's a much bigger problem for the second half. I think the concern is how far out do you place goods? Because if you think it's a spec add to the bu
componenttext: I think I did, but I'll say it again. Some manufacturers aren't even taking orders. That would imply that it's a much bigger problem for the second half. I think the concern is how far out do you place goods? Because if you think it's a spec add to the bubble you don't want to get very far out in terms of your placements. On the other hand, you can't sell air. So eventually you have to place the goods. The balancing act between the supplier and us typically the fall placements are done this time of year, it's very early in the cycle. So it's just the first couple of weeks of November. We expect in another month we'll be a lot smarter as to what the costing is going to be in early fall. It would be naive to say that we don't think it's a problem for apparel manufacturers and apparel retailers. I think we have an advantage for about 50% below an average price point to the department stores in the other end of the mall, so to the extent that our price points are sharp. And the customer wants to trade into a lower price point because prices are going up over all. I think that gives us an advantage.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010

componenttext: Our next question is coming from Bob Drbul with Barclays Capital.

componenttext: Just a couple of questions on the gross margin, you talked about Liz being off to a great start. Did you achieve a level that the gross margin sharing agreement kicked in and is there -- can you maybe help us talk about how it did add to your gross margin this quarter?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well we did launch, as you know, formerly launched since September, but a lot of the goods arrived in August. We're well ahead of our plan and not only in sales, but also in margin. So everything we said has paid off in terms of our ability to source the
componenttext: Well we did launch, as you know, formerly launched since September, but a lot of the goods arrived in August. We're well ahead of our plan and not only in sales, but also in margin. So everything we said has paid off in terms of our ability to source the goods, they were there in a timely way. The sell throughs were great. Virtually every single category achieved its projected plan and we're well above the margin number that we targeted.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the inventories, I think the outerwear sales had been a little bit disappointing for you. Has the sales the last couple of weeks helped you get outerwear inventories back in line to where you would expect them to be at this point?
componenttext: On the inventories, I think the outerwear sales had been a little bit disappointing for you. Has the sales the last couple of weeks helped you get outerwear inventories back in line to where you would expect them to be at this point?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're quite right. I mean outerwear is probably the weakest category. Women's and Men's were down 30% or 40% at one point on a season-to-date basis. I don't have the numbers right in front of me per yesterday. We're up around 30% month-to-date in Women's
componenttext: You're quite right. I mean outerwear is probably the weakest category. Women's and Men's were down 30% or 40% at one point on a season-to-date basis. I don't have the numbers right in front of me per yesterday. We're up around 30% month-to-date in Women's outerwear to give you an idea. So it's bouncing back obviously ours is a big part of the day after Thanksgiving business, so we think that we'll rescue much of the season on that topic. People need to wear outerwear when it eventually gets cold.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: You talked about some of the productivity levels of the Sephora store positioning. And overall, can you talk about comp store sales or the stores that do have Sephora in them versus the ones that don't?
componenttext: You talked about some of the productivity levels of the Sephora store positioning. And overall, can you talk about comp store sales or the stores that do have Sephora in them versus the ones that don't?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Typically, they're about 200 basis points higher than overall store performance when there's a Sephora inside the store week-to-week basis. We think that's because we're tracking new customers, younger customers, more affluent customers. We are quite grat
componenttext: Typically, they're about 200 basis points higher than overall store performance when there's a Sephora inside the store week-to-week basis. We think that's because we're tracking new customers, younger customers, more affluent customers. We are quite gratified by the comp numbers we're getting out of Sephora stores that have now been open over a year. If anything, they're above our expectations for this point in time. These 200 additional pop-up stores have Sephora product, Sephora owned product in the assortment â we think that'll be something that brings smaller stores and stores don't yet have Sephora a taste of what is yet to come. So I think both the LBMH and JCPenney feel that the partnership has been accretive to the overall support of our brand and certainly accretive to the traffic and the overall store sales.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Dana Telsey with Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Dana Telsey with Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about, give us a little bit more color on the Home business? Exactly what you're seeing there? How the margins are trending? On the breakdown of the gross margin, any way you can bucket the erosion and what you're looking for go-
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about, give us a little bit more color on the Home business? Exactly what you're seeing there? How the margins are trending? On the breakdown of the gross margin, any way you can bucket the erosion and what you're looking for go-forward.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what we've said is a modest decrease against the historic high in the margins. I would say it's probably more of a mix issue going forward assuming we get good sell through at point-of-sale. Our cadence clearance is now pretty much almost to the f
componenttext: I think what we've said is a modest decrease against the historic high in the margins. I would say it's probably more of a mix issue going forward assuming we get good sell through at point-of-sale. Our cadence clearance is now pretty much almost to the full year implementation, February being one year. I think the clearance issues that we experienced in July are not going to be repeated, so we feel more confident that will not be a factor. I think it's more predictable in the fourth quarter frankly. I think we've mentioned already is the catalog piece hopefully it will be passed that by the end of the quarter, but we don't expect any major surprises there. As to the overall Home business I mentioned earlier, housewares, particularly the coffee categories are very, very strong. The Luggage business which is more a profitable parts of your home happens to be one of the fastest-growing categories so that's obviously good news for Home margins. Margins in home have not been the issue, it's pretty more the customers' appetite for higher-priced big ticket merchandise. You know we have furniture on about 160 stores, our window cover and many more, more like 800 or 900 stores. So those are the toughest categories.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. The way we manage our margin and our markdowns, by the way we managed on a unit basis as opposed to marked down plan we've pretty much always ended on the right spot, because we forced the goods out of the store to meet the Unit number. So I d
componenttext: Absolutely. The way we manage our margin and our markdowns, by the way we managed on a unit basis as opposed to marked down plan we've pretty much always ended on the right spot, because we forced the goods out of the store to meet the Unit number. So I don't see a misalignment here. If anything, our clearing strategy, we're starting to get a cadence that we're more comfortable with selling the current splits earlier in the cycle which is accretive of not only to the margin rate, but it's also accretive to getting units out of the store faster.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Another question Mike, in your prepared remarks you mentioned the square footage growth and growth opportunities of the company longer-term. Was just hoping you could give a little more detail and give us your thoughts on the longer-term growth profile of
componenttext: Another question Mike, in your prepared remarks you mentioned the square footage growth and growth opportunities of the company longer-term. Was just hoping you could give a little more detail and give us your thoughts on the longer-term growth profile of the company? Maybe soft on what the company will look like in terms of mix between off and on mall, et cetera?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well you remember in the long range plan that up to 2014, it could take a look at the $3 billion of incremental volume we've seen and comparable store categories. We're virtually hitting every single one of those in growth things we have initiative that w
componenttext: Well you remember in the long range plan that up to 2014, it could take a look at the $3 billion of incremental volume we've seen and comparable store categories. We're virtually hitting every single one of those in growth things we have initiative that we've identified and this year and we'd expect to do the same in the coming years. The $1 billion in incremental volume in dotcom, frankly we're very confident about because we think the younger customers are really under penetrated on dotcom right now. We had that customer $27 million of them shopping on our store, that are not shopping yet with us online. That's a big opportunity for us to take the business from $1.5 billion to $2.5 billion. The last category, the third category is the billion dollar of incremental growth in store footprint or physical store environment. We expect to obviously find off mall 100,000 square-foot opportunities going forward. It's yet uncertain how many of those we can find in the time period. So far we've said about 75 it turns out to be 50 and 75 we do believe that there's smaller format opportunities that we can find that will be more urban or more suitable to markets where we already have a fairly big footprint, but we have in field [ph]opportunities. So that plus our big and tall off mall format that's not yet been announced in terms of its name but it will be approximately 300 stores as it rolls out. And we think that's a growth opportunity and then on the non-physical space in terms of the digital opportunities CLAD and Gifting Grace are also accretive to the overall growth of volume. So we still believe that $3 billion, $1 billion, $1 billion, the $5 billion incremental in the fourth and fifth years that is the right objective and we're preparing to go after it. Much of the investment we made in digital during the recession was to prepare ourselves to be able to grow these businesses and we're just now announcing what form that will take.

componenttext: For us, we've said in the past, that a presentation we made to the board an annual basis which we certainly intend to do again this year. When you're playing down 10% comp, obviously you want to survive that and more necessary. So there'll be more to say about that in the first year.

componenttextpreview: I wanted to get a little more information on remodels and what your experience has been with them this year and how that looks for next year? And specifically, how many stores have you and will you plan to completely remodel versus just touching some of t
componenttext: I wanted to get a little more information on remodels and what your experience has been with them this year and how that looks for next year? And specifically, how many stores have you and will you plan to completely remodel versus just touching some of these areas like Liz Claiborne and Mango?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let's start with one. Sephora goes in the store, essentially completely remodels the center core. So 75 of those each year and that's been a piece of what we've been doing. We probably had 20 or 30 major remodels that did not involve a Sephora, either bec
componenttext: Let's start with one. Sephora goes in the store, essentially completely remodels the center core. So 75 of those each year and that's been a piece of what we've been doing. We probably had 20 or 30 major remodels that did not involve a Sephora, either because of local conditions or an opportunity we decided to expand their footprint or whatever. The merchandising initiatives will be going to 600 stores and whether it be Mango or Call it Spring, those are much many call merchandising remodels, they're significant because particular in the case of the Mango, is at the front door, as well as Claiborne. So the customers deal with that is they think the whole store has been remodeled. But that's less of a capital commitment as planned in as part of the launch of the merchandise category. But as we mentioned we expected to take on over 300 major remodels within the five-year plan period that we'd like to believe that most of our customers, the results we get from the scorecard if you look at the key questions that where we score number one of our peer group is on claritive offer, lack of clutter, quality of fitting rooms, these are things that we believe that even in an unremodeled store that we execute extremely well in terms of store environment, uncluttered isles, availability of staffing, merchandise knowledge. Those are the things that frankly, we think define the customer experience. Having said that, we're going to invest in remodeling the stores to get them all to a level that we're proud of.

componenttext: Definitely. When Mango goes in the store, obviously it lifts all the contemporary pieces and also these accessories that's in the core, it's using next to Sephora, which is doing extremely well. The fine jewelry, which surprisingly is showing signs of life even in this economy again fine jewelry, Sephora, Mango and Claiborne are the pillars in the center core and the fact that our Fashion Jewelry business, the Modern Shoe business, the being an apparel business, modern shoes and handbags, these are all center core businesses. So we think that's but our focus for the year and it's paying off.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're going through our planning process now, Wayne. And looking at every aspect of our operation as we always do and really focused on what the initiatives will be and what kind of innovations it will take to invest to reduce and use resources mo
componenttext: I think we're going through our planning process now, Wayne. And looking at every aspect of our operation as we always do and really focused on what the initiatives will be and what kind of innovations it will take to invest to reduce and use resources more thoughtfully just like the jTime and the door to floor efforts. So we're going through that exercise at this point in time.

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Probably, the way that I would characterize Wayne, is that our same-store expense over the last four years is 9% less than four years ago, which by the way is the most aggressive reduction of our peers. Without a layoff, without a severance. That using th
componenttext: Probably, the way that I would characterize Wayne, is that our same-store expense over the last four years is 9% less than four years ago, which by the way is the most aggressive reduction of our peers. Without a layoff, without a severance. That using the technology and tools of jTime as well as door to floor. Our headquarters expense came off about 350 fewer associates in home office than we did it several years ago. This is with obviously technology and active attention to performance management. So obviously people that aren't doing as well are canceled out of business to allow us to continue to track the best talent and reward the best talent we have this year. Our view of expenses, it's a number, but more importantly is how do we run the business. And grow the business, we obviously have to invest but not with a blind eye towards what it costs. But having a single centralized organization that has now 10 years experience gives us a lot more confidence in systems investments and the tools we're using to be more aggressive in taking expense out.

componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on Liz and how that's impacting the overall women's apparel area. Obviously it's having some benefits in other categories. And just curious how you look at your women's apparel assortment now whether Liz and Mango are driving an overall i
componenttext: Just a follow-up on Liz and how that's impacting the overall women's apparel area. Obviously it's having some benefits in other categories. And just curious how you look at your women's apparel assortment now whether Liz and Mango are driving an overall increase that's with or better than the overall store. And then as you look at the continuum of traditional to trendy, looks like with Liz and American Living and more of the traditional side and Mango, on the trendier side, is there an opportunity in between there or particularly in the contemporary space for some new brand innovation?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're quite right. The contemporary piece of it is much smaller than the updated modern or the classic piece of our business. Conceptually, we lead it with Claiborne on the pad that's adjacent to American Living both are doing extremely well. As a matter
componenttext: You're quite right. The contemporary piece of it is much smaller than the updated modern or the classic piece of our business. Conceptually, we lead it with Claiborne on the pad that's adjacent to American Living both are doing extremely well. As a matter of fact, American Living has benefited from adjacency of the Claiborne success. I wouldn't over state the size of MNG compared to the Claiborne business they're completely different business. The key is up 3x more productive than any other contemporary brand we have in the space. So it's obviously resonating, it's the only fast fashion in a department store in the country and when you say fast fashion it's not a 30 week cycle the most important fashion pieces are in a two to three week cycle. Somebody can say they had fast fashion, you say compared to what? I think the customer has been trained that they want what they see on the runway. They want what they see in Sarah, H&M, Forever 21, Mango, these are looks that they're expecting to see. We think it brings the right kind of patina to our business, that there's a reason to come to the store more often. And our biggest opportunity, Frank, is more frequent visits. We always look for white space. I would say that a.n.a. and Worthington are huge private brands that are very, very successful, operating much higher margin than national brands and theyâre modern brands, so they do fill that space between the classic and the contemporary space. And just like the rest of the private brand businesses, we like the fact that they're going faster than national brands because that says that the customer is voting for the merchandise that we've designed and built at higher profitability.

componenttext: Let me say of our seven major merchandise group there's only one that has a comp store decline for the year. Which is Home, which is I think 2% down for the year. You'd have to say it's been accretive in the sense that all the businesses are growing. Men's obviously had a much stronger Father's Day period than Women's but Women's had a slow start to the year, but has come in strong in the second half.

componenttext: The new Growth Brands Division sounds like you already are trying to leverage some of your current core competency and it also sounds like you've been spending on these over the last few years. Should we expect these initiatives to be accretive out of the gate? Dilutive? Or you could just give us some idea on the timeline of that?

headline: J. C. Penney Company, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we have certainly planned on not to be accretive in the early days. These are important partnerships. We've announced with the first properties.  We believe this allows us to accelerate the development of these brands because they start with an au
componenttext: I think we have certainly planned on not to be accretive in the early days. These are important partnerships. We've announced with the first properties.  We believe this allows us to accelerate the development of these brands because they start with an audience that's addressable. To start the dotcom or digital idea today and just have to market your way to visibility is extremely expensive and has not been particularly successful in most cases. So we think we have an advantage in terms of being accretive earlier. But I think it would be wrong to say that we expect them to contribute right away. So we built in our investment there, we've been investing as I've mentioned, and we think we're prepared now to introduce a few of our ideas and there'll be more.

componenttext: On the promotional calendar for the fourth quarter, are there any shifts that we should be aware of versus last year? And then maybe just a follow-up on that point, do you believe that the pricing in the channel is rational at this point?

componenttextpreview: I think so. I think most of the key competitors are promoting their business for the cadence that the customer understands and that we think it will be a promotional period because we're a promotional department store. We don't think we'll be experiencing
componenttext: I think so. I think most of the key competitors are promoting their business for the cadence that the customer understands and that we think it will be a promotional period because we're a promotional department store. We don't think we'll be experiencing kind of irrational behavior. The calendar itself has one additional day between Thanksgiving and Christmas, that's not of our design, I guess that was Julius Caesar that did that, but if you're asking about Thanksgiving. So I suspect there won't be any big surprise.
